Of all the types of tomato I've ever tried to grow here, the Pink Egg is the only one that I'd say has "worked". Others have survived for a certain period and given a few resentful, bland tomatoes but the pink eggs produce like mad and they taste quite good, and don't have any problem with pests, disease, or cracking like the others do. The fruit is beautiful colours and the size is between a cherry and a roma. They produce well in the dry season and will keep growing through the wet (but will not fruit, the humidity messes with pollination). If you nurse them through a wet season they'll start fruiting again as soon as the weather dries up a bit.

The seeds were started inside in a sunny south window, then trained on a balcony facing south and put on a balcony facing nw early in the summer (probably end of May, start of June). 

Two plants have more sun than the others and are giving a lot more tomatoes. The one tomato plant in the most shade is not doing well now that the weather is turning a bit colder and the sun isn't around as much as in the summer. Will not give crop, so do not put tomatoes there, unless higher up (more sun, warmer).

The plants directly on the floor and in the smallest containers (planted alone) are doing worst, while those in bigger containers and together (2 and 2) have gotten big and at the time being (17.9.2014) turning tomatoes red daily.

attributes.name: Carrot
attributes.description: The carrot is a root vegetable. It is usually orange in color, but some cultivars are purple, black, red, white, and yellow. The most commonly eaten part of the plant is the taproot, but the greens are sometimes eaten as well. The leaves appear first, and the taproot grows more slowly beneath the soil. Fast-growing cultivars mature within three months of sowing the seed. Slower-maturing cultivars are harvested four months after sowing.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct Seed, thin to 3cm apart when seedlings are 8cm high

attributes.name: Coriander
attributes.description: Coriander is the English (UK) name for Cilantro. In America, Coriander is used to refer to the dried round seeds of the Cilantro plant, which have a warm, spicy flavor and are used in curries, pickles, sausages, soups, and stews. The essential oil of the seeds is used in herbal remedies and dietary supplements, and to flavor liqueurs, gin, vermouth, tobacco, and perfumes. Cilantro is an annual herb in the Apiaceae family with soft leaves that are broadly lobed at the base of the plant and become slender and feathery higher up the stems. The leaves will be ready to harvest within 50-55 days, the seeds take up to 100 days to mature and then need to be dried.

attributes.name: Rosemary
attributes.description:
Rosmarinus officinalis, commonly known as rosemary, is a woody, perennial herb with fragrant, evergreen, needle-like leaves and white, pink, purple, or blue flowers, native to the Mediterranean region.
It is a member of the mint family Lamiaceae, which includes many other herbs. The name "rosemary" derives from the Latin for "dew" (ros) and "sea" (marinus), or "dew of the sea". The plant is also sometimes called 'anthos', from the ancient Greek word , meaning "flower". Rosemary has a fibrous root system.

attributes.name: Strawberry
attributes.description:
Strawberries are a hybrid species of the genus Fragaria that produce sweet, bright red fruits. 

There are three main types of strawberries: 

1) summer-fruiting: produce a single, large crop of fruit the year after planting. To grow, transplant plugs or crowns in early spring in rows spaced at least 120cm apart. Pinch off all flowers the first season and train the plant's runners, pressing them into the soil 15-22cm apart from the mother plant. Mulch with straw or pine needles in the fall when the plants have died back. When the plants start to grow back in the spring, move the mulch aside. After harvest the second season, set a lawnmower to about 10cm high and mow, being sure not to damage crowns.

 The other two types are 

2) Ever-bearing and 3) Day Neutral, both of which send out less runners and bear several crops of smaller fruit throughout the season. These two types can be grown using raised beds about 20cm high and 60cm wide. Transplant crowns or plugs in staggered double rows, about 30cm apart. Remove runners and flowers until July of the first year to give the roots time to develop, and then allow plants to produce fruit. All types of strawberries begin to produce fewer and less sweet fruit once they are two years or older. Because strawberries are a hybrid, seeds will not breed true. Strawberries are predominantly propagated using bare root plugs or crowns or dividing runners. Make sure not to bury the crown when transplanting plugs.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant bare root plants/plugs or divide runners

12/11/2017 something is eating the fruit before us. Snails, slugs? slaters?

26/11/2017 Shovelled compost next to them.

14/01/2018 added sheep pellets
Lifted and renewed strawberry bed in 2018
Everbearing strawberries that overwintered from last year's plantings. As of 2013-04-12, covered in flowers and looking very healthy!
Transplanted some and bought new ones
Seedlings. 1 wintered over from last year.
Seedlings in a pot in the afternoon window
8 "Shuksan" June-bearing, which flourish, and have sent out many runners and new plants since.
"Quinalt" everbearing, of which 4 died in 2012 and they have barely grown.
"Tribute" day-neutral, filling in for the holes left by the dying Quinaults.
bought at Home Depot

2013-05-06: Planted who-knows-when by the previous tenants. Seems to be doing OK.

2013-05-18: Flowering!

Everbearing variety

Going on year 5 with the strawberries, learning a lot. 

Need to really stay on top of the runners. Keep control. 

Last year we lost most of our plants because we didn't prune bak enough. 

Added new plants this year, intend to keep a close watch on the runners and not let them propagate uncontrolled.
Most of our strawberries are around the orchard fence and next to the patio--where the chickens shouldn't be able to get to them. We have many different varieties.
white alpine strawberries
Mix of strawberry varieties in a tiered bed, in window boxes on the ground, and in a holey old rain barrel.
Perennials. Not dead yet.

Alpine strawberries. Originally planted 2010 from starts bought at the U-District Farmers Market.  These are my 2nd favorite (out of what i grow) after the rainier strawberries.  THESE MIGHT BE DEAD -- might not have survived a recent super-hot spell -- unsure yet.
Tri-star strawberries. Originally planted 2010 from starts bought at the U-District Farmers Market.  These are okay, if the rainier strawberries aren't fruiting at the time.
Still going strong; have some wire netting tunnelled over it to deter chooks. Sharing with birds.
We had strawberries in hanging pots, and they grew huge runners during the last month.  Time to transplant them to the actual garden and separate the big plants.
on a balcony with evening sun.  Lots of feeders, but not many flowers or berries.  Low on pollination, made most flowers fail.
"Roman" variety. A freebie from Diggers Club.
This is the white alpine variety

Potted in March, separated off from a plant which was originally planted 2011-01-09. Growing on north-facing balcony.

Separated into many smaller plants in (northern hemisphere) summer 2013.

2014-01-05: Some, but not all, of the plants were damaged by frost in late Dec 2013. Supplemented the remaining plants by new ones of a different (much smaller) variety.

2014-04-20: Repotted small strawberries into a small earthbox on the north-facing balcony.

2014-08-30: Dug up a bunch of the larger strawberry plants which were in 4 separate pots. Expect to replant some into a large earthbox and give the rest away.

2014-09-10: Migrated most of the larger strawberries to an earthbox on the north-facing balcony. There are still a few others in 2 separate pots.
Quinault everbearing

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: Planted a 6 pack of strawberries in the strawberry jar that holds my herbs. 2 died but 4 are doing well.
Planted in a variety of places on both the north and south facing balconies.
Planted 28 seascape ever everbearring dry root plants in temporary beds # 13 & 14
3 varieties perennial strawberry, 1 June-bearing, 2 ever-bearing

Rainier strawberries.  Originally planted 2010 from starts bought at the U-District Farmers Market.  These are my favorite of the strawberries i grow.  Usually have fruit mid-/late-june.  These are doing really well this year since i transplanted them and gave them a healthy sprinkling of fertilizer.  Right now there are so many babies hanging off of runners that it looks like a spider plant.

2014:  Moved to Cobweb Cottage.

Half of this patch was intended to be strawberries, but I think the raspberries are going to take over.  It's just as well.  The strawberries did not do good last year.  The ants got some, and the rest seemed to rot on the ground.  I need to find a variety that holds the berries up above the plant, or something.  And see about getting rid of the ants, perhaps.  A few varieties were bought, and a few were collected from my folks' garden.  
July 2015 - these are totally buried under the raspberries.  Only a few plants survived, and I've seen two small strawberries.

Sent to me as seedlings by @katjnz on twitter

Transplanted to fence (near feijoa tree) 2019-09-08
Planted in 2015 and still going in 2016
west side of garden by strawberry neighbor.

Attempting to start alpine strawberries from seed. Used Mignonette cultivar from Renee's Garden supplier and organic jiffy-pods. Currently on window sill for warmth. Expect seedling in 2 to 4 weeks. ETA 14 April 2013 -- seedling coming up, very small and fragile.  Transplanted to plastic pots with more dirt 25-May-2013. 27 July 2013 -- one plant surviving and thriving as an outside plant in my container garden -- as large as my fist, which is pretty good for a strawberry plant that was seed 4 months ago.
Mulched with straw
10 trough planters with 12 plants in each

5 ever-bearing, 5 seasonal.  Planted them all around the feet of the trees in the orchard.

Garden Pea (germinate 6-10 days)
I planted 3 short rows, 6 inches apart so they can climb on each other
After they grow 6 inches tall, thin so plants are 6-8 inches apart.  Produces 26-28 inch vines.  Pick often to produce more.  3.5 in pods.  Days to maturity: 68

Started picking July 3.  These are for the pea, not the pod
Sugar snap peas
Mammoth pea
3 stakes each with about 8 seeds. Stakes nearest the back of the garden.

Snow Pea, Avalanche
Planted 3 short rows (about 7 ft long), 6 inches apart so they climb on each other.  Bamboo sticks needed to hold them up.  
After seedlings grow 6 inches, thin so plans are 6-8 inches apart.  Produces 30 inch vines.  Harvest often to encourage new growth.  Produces dark green 6 inch pods.
Days to maturity: 59

Started harvest July 2nd so they matured in about 50 days!  These are great tasting pods.  Grown for the pod, not the pea.  Pick when peas are visible

attributes.name: Radish
attributes.description: Radishes are fast-growing cool season root vegetables in the Brassica family. Their taproots come in variety of shapes, sizes, and colors and have a sharp, spicy taste. They are usually eaten raw and added to salads. Radishes need cool weather and moist soil - they do not do well in hot, dry environments. More growing information is available in individual species entries.

attributes.description: Kale is a cultivar of the species Brassica oleracea. It has green or purple leaves that branch off from one to multiple upright stems and do not form a head like cabbage. The plant is usually grown as an annual, but if grown as a perennial, it will form seeds in the second year. Current popular varieties include Curly kale, Italian kale, and Red Russian kale (green leaves with pale purple stems). It can be grown as baby salad greens or for bunching adult leaves. Leaves are sweeter after a frost and delicious eaten raw, added to salads, sauted, or added to stews and casseroles.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed. If planting indoors, harden off before transplanting seedlings outside.

plantings.description: Seeded dino/Tuscan/black kale on 1 March, germinated ~9 March, thinned 26 March.
"blue curled scotch"
put some kale in plant starter
Two kale plants, one red and one green, from the farmer's market--planted into pots on my shaded porch.

seedlings from that nursery on Leith St. half cavalo nero, half red russian.

Finished the red russian stuff back in about October; the cavalo nero (or wait, was it a second planting? I have lost track) is still going strong in December.

Kale is another family favorite--when we can't grow it, we buy a couple of bunches of it every week and put it in everything.

Last year's harvest wasn't overwhelmingly awesome, but I was able to add it to a meal a couple of times a week from half a dozen tiny plants. This year, we're planting ALL THE KALE in ALL THE PLACES. Because it's important to us :)

Everything I read about growing kale always says that a handful of plants will feed the whole neighborhood. Sadly, last year our handful of plants were so scraggly that they hardly fed us. 

This year I'm going a little more kale crazy--under the lights, wintersown, and probably some direct seeded. I'd be thrilled to have a "too much kale" problem! :)
Starts from the basement grow lights.

Red kale.

Planted in egg carton cups.

The hope is that they'll sprout nicely and can be transferred to the Balcony Container Garden.
Large pots.
Reasonably productive, production picking up more now. Some of the plants started out very small, and are just really getting going now. About 10 lbs harvested by now.

2 curly kale, 1 lacinato.

The seedlings were purchased from a local hardware store. They're quite large (~20cm) and healthy looking.

dwarf kale, half planted in the long pot with the sorrel, half planted in their own pot

24/1/2014 The individual pot is finished but the ones in the pot with sorrel still going, a little raggedy.
Blue Curled Scotch Kale seedlings, purchased online and delivered via mail from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com). Plants are still producing beautifully almost a full year later!
Seedlings from CERES. 8 cavalo nero, 8 blue something something.  Planted in big containers in the front yard.  Some interplanted with chard and lettuce, some alone.

Old seed; some sprouting inside earlier in the year so hopefully still viable.

17 October: not sure if seedlings coming up are mesclun or them - or a mix. Patch very dry.

...I don't even really like kale but the earwigs keep eating the chard leaves

Well, they like the kale too, but one or two are still hanging on.

Of 6 planted, 2 still survive, but the sheep got in and ate most of one.
I transplanted 1 big kale and one baby kale from my old house to the new place.
Old seed, expired 2013. Sowed the last, not sure if they're still viable. Haven't seen any of the previous sowing come up.
I think we should have planted these earlier, maybe in autumn or winter, but I really like kale so I figured we'd give it a go anyway. I planted some marigolds nearby to try to keep the pests off.

Started seeds indoors. Used food growing method: place seeds in mouth, under tongue for 9 mins; hold in hand and breath over them; hold to celestial bodies for at least 30 seconds; plant with fingers/toes and wait 3 days to water

204-10-29: Planted 4 kale in earthbox (with spinach and garlic) on north-facing balcony. Planted 2 with herbs in railing basket on north-facing balcony.

2015-01-19: Got a different variety of kale. Planted 1 kale with lemon tree and 1 kale in separate pot on south-facing balcony. Planted 3 kale in second earthbox (with broccoli) on north-facing balcony.

2015-01-25: Harvested some of the first round of kale.

2015-05-02: Harvested most of the remaining kale. (Harvested several other times since the last update, and some regrew.)

2015-05-24: We actually have a bit of one kale left, since it keeps re-growing, but the others are all past done.

attributes.name: Cherry Tomato
attributes.description: Cherry tomatoes range in size from a thumbtip to the size of a golf ball. Their shape ranges from spherical to slightly oblong to pointed at the bottom. They are often red, but can also be yellow, green, striped, and even black. More oblong cherry tomatoes often share characteristics with plum tomatoes, and are known as grape tomatoes. Cherry tomatoes can be quite sweet (such as the Sungold or Sunsweet yellow varieties), more traditionally acidic, or deep in flavor. They are delicious for snacking, in salads, lightly roasted or grilled, or baked. They require little to no pruning unlike larger tomato plants.
attributes.sowing_method: Sow seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before the last expected frost

These are just ordinary yellow onions, planted from sets.  They went in a little late this year, but the ground was very wet from Christmas onwards, and I didn't want them to rot in the ground. They're in one of the long, narrow plots at the top of the garden, which is sheltered but gets the sun for a good bit of the day.  They've done well there before.

When tops have dried out, clip off an inch from bulb and store in ventilated area.  Preferred way is in panty hose or wrap each in newspaper.  Try to keep from them touching each other

attributes.description: Potatoes are starchy root vegetables in the Solanaceae, or Nightshade, family, which also includes tomatoes, eggplants, and peppers. They originated in South America, and spread to become a worldwide staple. The leaves and fruit are usually poisonous and the stem tuber is the only edible part once it is cooked. The potato can be cooked in many ways, brewed into alcohol, and also used as the basis for creating bioplastics. More growing information is available in individual species entries.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors after last frost. Each piece must have one eye.

Planted two (new) jumbo garbage cans with the pre-sprouted (organic) white potatoes and red potatoes, left over from winter.  I cut potatoes with several sprouts into pieces and allowed them to air-dry for a couple days; left smaller potatoes whole.  Laid down a bed of about 6 inches organic potting soil (compost-rich) in the bottom of each barrel, then placed potato starts sprout-side up (white in one barrel, red in the other), across the surface.  Pressed each piece down slightly to ensure contact.  Then lightly scattered an additional inch or two of soil over the top to cover the sprouts, and sprinkled with water.  I plan to continue adding soil as needed to keep the main stem covered, until the plants nearly reach the top of the barrel -- then I'll let the vines grow, to gather energy for the tubers that will develop underground. I should be able to set the barrels outside in a month or two (before they get too heavy), and I'm looking forward to buckets of potatoes when the vines die back (Julyish?).  Wish me luck!

Having never grown Garlic before I purchased 6 bulbs of softneck, organic garlic from Digger's Club. And as you do I proceeded to plant out every square inch that I could find with garlic cloves.

So far everything has sprouted and is between 10 and 20 cm tall now. So I'm calling it a massive success. The problem will be when we harvest and have stupid amounts of garlic to eat and use but I figure we can get through 2 or 3 bulbs a week. 

I've mixed in plantings of carrot and asian cabbage (mostly Bok Choi) around the garlic.

Planted these from the bulbs I grew last year. Half hardneck and half softneck.

Got scapes! Early may.

Softneck: Harvested early jun. 9 undersized bulbs, of which 4 were severely damaged by rodents.  Chose not to attempt another crop from this stock. Will either plant all hardneck or purchase new stock.

Hardneck: Harvested jun 22. 13 full size and 1 undersize bulbs, of which 2 were lightly damaged by rodents.

This is a soft neck garlic that I have been planting and saving over the last 10 years, so I now have a garlic that really likes our soil and climate. I have saved the biggest and best cloves from this years seed crop and keep them aside to plant in really good soil to provide bulbs for next years seed crop - these I will plant in the next week or so.
The ones I have just planted are the second best from the seed crop - we will eat all of these over 6 months or so (they will keep this long) and there will be enough to give a load away.
I  have another 24 to put in yet
Sometimes we have a very mild winter and the garlic stay as one huge bulb, apparently if garlic don't get cold then the bulbs do not split into cloves. To stop this happening I put my cloves in the fridge for a week before planting and then they get half an hour in the freezer just prior to going in the ground.
I put a pinch of FBB dug into the soil below the clove to give the garlic a yummy start and always plant in wet soil to get the roots growing right away

Actually California Softneck Garlic
California Softneck Garlic

**CHESNOK RED** (Standard Purple Stripe - Hardneck)
Our best Purple Stripe in performance year after year. A great cooking garlic, it retains  avor and texture. Very large bulbs that average 9 to 10 easy to peel cloves. From Shvelisi, Republic of Georgia. One of our best baking garlics.

**MUSIC** (Porcelain - Hardneck)
An outstanding plant producing very large bulbs. A starchy-sweet garlic when baked. Hot when consumed raw.

**METECHI** (Marbled Purple Stripe - Hardneck)
Plants upright and broader leaved than others. Large capsule and bulbils. Cloves few, but large and fat, with blushed and lined skins. Tastes fiery raw, but with a nice  finish.

**ASIAN TEMPEST** (Asiatic - Hardneck)
From South Korea via Horace Shaw in Oregon. Beak on bulbil can reach 18 inches in length. This strain produces an outstanding crop. Sweet baked with good garlic  flavor. Breathtaking raw.

**INCHELIUM RED** (Artichoke - Softneck)
Large bulbed vigorous strain; our best selling Artichoke. A top rated softneck at a 1990 taste test at Rodale kitchens. Discovered on the Colville Indian Reservation by Larry Geno; original source unknown. Four to five clove layers with 8 to 20 cloves. It seems to have higher soluble solids (denser, heavier bulbs) than other Artichokes. Mild,  flavorful.

**SILVER WHITE** (Silverskin - Softneck)
Originally a California strain from Harmony Farm Supply. This large bulbed garlic has proven productive in both cold winter/hot summer and humid maritime climates. Our most productive Silverskin since 1992.

**PERSIAN STAR** (Purple Stripe - Hardneck)
Vivid clove wrapper col- ors. Outer bulb wrapper sometimes smooth white, but inner wrappers purple streaked. Red-tipped cloves with marbled streaks on whitish or yellow-brown back ground. Very pleasant  flavor, mildly spicy but not too sharp. Purchased in Samarkand, at a Uzbekistan bazaar in the late 1980s by John Swenson.

**MONTANA ZEMO** (Porcelain - Softneck)
Original source likely Zemo. This beautiful, large leafed porcelain strain is more vigorus than "Zemo", producing large, dense bulbs. Grown by Foothill Farm at the base of the Mission Mountains in NW Montana.

**CHINA STRIPE** (Turban - Hardneck)
Delicate purple stripes adorn this attractive bulb. Mild flavor. Purchased in Beijing market by G. Czarnecki.

**RUSSIAN RED** (Marbled Purple Stripe - Hardneck)
Has a flavor similar to Rocamboles in its complexity. Purple bulb wrappers. Clove wrappers are brown and purple.

**RED TOCH** (Artichoke - Softneck)
Collected in Rep. of Georgia by Hanelt about 1988, near the town of Tochliavri. Bulb wrappers streaked with red, pink and yellow . A very popular strain for good reason.

**NOOTKA ROSE** (Silverskin - Softneck)
A well colored strain; a Northwest heirloom from the San Juan Islands
off the Washington coast. From Steve Bensel of Nootka Rose Farm in Waldron, WA. Cloves streaked pink on mahogany background with solid red clove tips. Colors fade in rich soil. Medium to large bulbs and very attractive braided. Strong flavor.

2014:  Started from seed.  Moved to Cobweb Cottage.

2015:  Flowers, zomg!
This sage variety has huge leaves like I've never seen before.  Hopefully it won't get too obnoxious in the hell strip by the street.
It was there when I moved in
14 November 2015: needs bigger pot!
Broad Leaf Sage
Seed starter.
http://judielainenaturalist.postach.io/post/lamiaceae-nepetoideae-mentheae-salvia-officinalis
Purple sage

Planted in herb basket on north-facing balcony.

Succumbed to frost sometime in late Dec.

Planted in railing container, will thin out afterward.

2021-04-22 : Two weeks in, still no seedling in sight, researches indicate up to a month. Should have began indoor.

2021-04-26 : First seedlings.
No signs of growth, buried it outside anyway.
Single seedling in a pot.
4 zucchini seedlings from Bunnings. All productive.
2 giant zucchini plants from the Bullens. Very productive.

Raised from seed, hothouse to begin and transplanted out on the 08/04/2013.

Didn't expect all six seeds to sprout, currently have a couple of plants sharing a large pot but expect will need to cull one or two.

One set of seeds has not been transplanted.
2 zucchini plants in split peat pots, will see how they do. One is half-under the forsythia; a tomato plant ate the forsythia last year, so I figured I'd see if a squash vine was up for it!
From seedling. It said plant it in a hill... so I just dumped a bunch of top soil in a pile and called it good. :D?

These are in peat pots to start, since I have repeatedly failed at growing zucchini from seed.

All of the seeds seem to have sprouted! The four that did very well are transplanted; one pot left with two v. young sprouts in it.
Bottom half of terrace; bottom row. 3 Aristocrat zucchini.

After experimenting with both zucchini and yellow squash in our garden last year, this year we opted to just grow zucchini since the yellow squash never seemed to do anything.

This year, after fertilizing our garden with composted sheep manure gifted from our new flock, we have some happy zucchini that give us 2 - 8 zucchinis a day.

Last two squash seedlings - these were slow to come up and stunted, but they did all right once they were up, so in the ground they went. The soil here isn't great - it's over a utility line and they dumped all our good loam and filled in with subsoil - but it was the space I had left.
Yellow summer squash - got lucky enough to find two healthy sprouts in one cell!

Seedling zach gave me from some sort of anarchist farmers market. Globe zucchini.

It had 4 little round zucchinis and then died!

$2 plants from Whole Food, cultivars unknown. Cut off the flowers in an effort to get the plants to put more effort into roots and leaves for the moment. In the corn patch, which is really more of a milpa now.
Zucchini

Astia 
first harvest 7/20
Planted 2, only one came up thank goodness! In 3x3 an it's taking over!!! Already got 2 giant zucchinis!

Organic Black Beauty zucchini, purchased from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com). I was trying to companion-plant it with the Glass Gem corn, but it was quickly overshadowed and crowded out. I've seen a few flowers but no fruit. I must be the only gardener in the world who has failed to grow zucchini! :( (You can see a few leaves in the lower left corner of this photo)
2 summer squash plants, grown from seed, transplanted! See if they will actually grow - they were fine until I transplanted them...
One fordhook near the letterbox, one yellow straightneck under my bedroom window.  Well, I say one of each, but actually three seeds in each spot, which will be thinned in due course.
A couple of different kinds of zucchini.  Two were planted from seedling, and two from seed.

Might technically be semi-shade, the fence shades it from about 3pm, has been doing well, no sign of fungal disease (but it is the dry season at the moment). Seeded directly into compost pile  (soil is a horrible clay) and heavily mulched with sugar cane mulch. Watered solely by inground lawn sprinkler irrigation system 3 times a week due to it's location.
Tromboncino from Diggers.

I forgot to water it in the morning, and then it hit 86F. It was very wilted and droopy when I got home. I dunked the whole peat pot in the watering can, stuck it in the ground, and watered some more. I hope it survives.

So, 12 hours later, with a rainstorm last night, the once-super-floppy zucchini looks perfectly happy and healthy. Yay! (I just uploaded a photo of the seedlings. The staked one is the straightneck squash)

Only ended up getting one fruit off this.
Black Jack variety.
courgette de Nice  fruit rond.
last year's seeds
Update  24/04/15 - 2 Seelings have been settled in the garden bed.
In greenhouse
Potted on in greenhouse
Planted into NW bed.

Marked with very small canes.

Otherwise known as a courgette.
I planted one other zucchini along the back of the house, and it seems to hate it there.  It may be dead.  On the other hand, the two I planted in the "hell strip" are thriving.

Last of the packet!

None germinated, but two seedlings started elsewhere in the garden were moved in.
two plants about 60 cm apart within dripper lines
Golden zucchini
south side
long green trailing
suffering from powdery mildew. Pulled as too weak.
Grey Zucchini, thrives and produced crop of enormous fruit.
3 more from school
Yellow courgette

attributes.description: Chives are a perennial herb in the Allium genus related to garlic, shallots, leeks, scallions, and Chinese onions. They are grown for culinary and ornamental purposes. The scapes or stems are hollow and tubular and have a mild onion taste. They are one of the fines herbes of French cuisine and commonly used fresh. The plant forms dense clusters of slender 2-3cm bulbs, which can be cooked. Chive flowers are edible, star-shaped, and pale purple. Chives are a good companion plant because their sulfur compounds repel negative insects, and their flowers attract bees.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed. If planting indoors, harden off before transplanting seedlings outside.

plantings.description:
Originally planted 2011 from a start bought at the U-District Farmers Market.

2014:  Moved to Cobweb Cottage.
2 bunches of chives from the Bullens. Growing well.

moved this from the  middle of the yard (which was previously a 100X50 vegetable garden allowed to go to weed by former homeowners, but the chives survived. It would tolerate me mowing it down, and making the neighborhood smell like onions, and keep growing till I had a better spot to put it)

I'm still picking grass out which is intertwined with the root ball, but it is as hearty as ever.
Planted in the corner railing box of winter survivors
survivors from last year, in the strawberry pot.

owner.location: East Coast, Central Vancouver Island, BC, Canada

plantings.description: Now in Veg table, becoming Huge so will divide later in the year.

chewed to the ground late season by deer.

May 2014: one plant did not survive the extreme winter. The other plant is being repeatedly chewed.
normal
From a pot from the old house.

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: In the narrow area beside the driveway.
planted a little cluster of seeds in each hole in seed tray, interested in seeing if that works better.
This will be an companion plant for the tomatoes, as they repel aphids and whitefly.

I dug this up from the old garden and brought to Ballarat with me.  It was unhappy for a while, but finally took off in the spring of 2014.  As it flowered and the heads dried out, I picked them off and tucked them under the mulch around where I hope more will grow next year.  Let's see how that works out!
Chives are by the kitchen door, where they come in very handy.
2 clumps of chives.  Will see how they do here.  Clay soil.
Chives from Takoma Park farmers market
Planted a load of herb seeds. Let's see what appears.
The sole survivor of the winter of 2014/2015!
in the herb planter

attributes.name: Thyme
attributes.description: Thyme is a perennial evergreen herb in the Lamiaceae (Mint) family. It is related to Oregano. Thyme is cold-hardy to -28.8 C and a perennial in US Hardiness zones 5-8. Thyme can live for 5-6 years but needs to be divided or replaced after 3-4 years. It can be used fresh or dried to season dishes.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant cuttings or seedlings or direct seed indoors

plantings.description: Overwintered 2011-12 just fine, not sure if it's going to come back this time. And it did! Though I will need to figure out how to disentangle it from all the dead bits.
Pretty darn hardy. Has managed to grow despite the profusion of weeds.
Seeds in trough next to established plant.

Lemon thyme and ordinary thyme, which I dug up from the old garden and brought to Ballarat with me.  The lemon thyme died and the ordinary stuff seems to be rather overwhelmed by a giant sage bush that took over the area they're in; perhaps I should move it.

Date inaccurate.

Planted on north-facing balcony.

had to replace the original plant, as I let the oregano overtake. Keeping a closer eye on it now. 
Great for drying
Growing slowly!
Bought at Ace hardware
2 English thyme plants. Total of 3 thyme plants in herb garden.
Herb planter
Trying to root cuttings, let's see if it works!
Received as gift, don't remember exactly when. Growing in pot.
French Thyme seedlings acquired from Sloat Garden Center at 3rd Ave & Clement.
Bought from Waldeck's, planted by Bilby.

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: English thyme. Planted in hanging planter box from back porch railing. Purchased online from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com). Great stuff, use it constantly!
growing and growing. lemon thyme
Seedling from Abbotsford farmer's market. Has some small flowers on it.
3 x 'silver posy' very pretty in the garden as well as tasty.
First time trying to grow thyme from seed.

14 November 2015: needs bigger pot!
seed starts for community garden plot

Lime thyme, planted in the pot that holds the tiny lime tree. It flourishes!

Note: It only flourished in the summer. It seems not to get enough sun in the winter and mostly died back.

Oregano in punnet from Bunnings.

Planted with Italian Parsley.

2013-05-18: Planted from seed next to the lemon coriander.

2013-06-02: Finally starting to sprout.

Grows like a weed. I take cuttings several times a year to dry for use throughout the year.
Occasionally I have to divide to keep it in control of the space available.
Herb planter

in second raised bed with tomato, thyme, and lemon thyme.

plantings.description: Italian oregano (from D. Landreth Seed Co., 2011). Sprinkled some onto dirt in a jiffy pot. We'll see how many (if any) i get.

Greek oregano.  Planted 2013.  Purchased from U-District Street Fair.

2014:  Moved to Cobweb Cottage.
Planted three different varieties - common oregano, golden oregano, and greek oregano. Also scattered a number of seeds (bought online) of common oregano

Purchased at the local hardware store.

Very tall and hardy seedlings. If I don't miss too many waterings, they should do well.
Second year. Doing well, but gets overwhelmed by the arugula and parsley.
Greek oregano. Planted in a hanging planter box off my back porch railing. Purchased online from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com). Doing great, I use it ALL the time!
In the narrow area beside the driveway.

Planted in a rectangular container with parsley and something else.

Still keeps going in the mild winter of 2015.
mixed varieties

Date is from likely-oldest plant. Some are descendants.

Planted in pots on north-facing balcony.

Ridiculously productive. Gave away several plants in summer 2013, retired another. Now down to a manageable quantity.

2014-08-31: Bought a new oregano plant. Retired one old retired oregano plant to dry, gave another away.

2014-10-06: New oregano has come up in the space we'd previously grown oregano, and the new oregano has started growing a bunch as well, so we gave away the last of our old oregano.

Oregano in a small pot on the sunny porch railing. Often pinched for cooking!
Hanging in there but it has a rough time over the winter.
Oregano over seeded in 6 seed flat cells.
Greek Oregano
"Italian hot" oregano.

Hot and spicy oregano and greek oregano.

The greek oregano didn't make it through the winter. Just as well. It was too invasive and didn't have a good oregano 'bite'.
Italian oregano, planted in hanging basket
Hot and spicy oregano, grown indoors beside a well-lit window

attributes.name: Arugula
attributes.description: Mildly bitter, sometimes peppery, salad green. Fast-growing with deeply lobed leaves. Prefers cooler weather, bolts in the heat.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed or transplant in wide rows or raised beds

plantings.description: Rocket
Baker Creek Heirloom arugula

It started trying to bolt in mid-march.

EDIT: Went to seed in the garden. Got "wild" arugula growing all over the place this year.
Hopefully it will replace the bolting arugula. I dunno though it may already be too hot.
caterpillars are eating it

Prolific. Goes to seed, sends seedlings everywhere. It now grows as a weed in my garden. Crop is stupendous. Cutback mid-July after going to seed. Resprouting now, should have second crop ready in early fall.
sprinkled seeds in seed tray... too tiny to plant indiviually
This is my first attempt at Arugula. I would say 90% of the seeds sprouted and it looks like it will be full blown Arugula one day.
Was given a store bought packet of rocket as a gift. Thought i'd give it a try. It has grown well but is bitter as hell and tough as anything. Now the only ones who eat it are the worms.

attributes.description: Typically grown for its round or cylindrical taproot, the leaves of the beet are also edible. Leaves resemble Swiss chard on a smaller scale and are good sauted. The taproot, or beet, ranges in color from deep red to gold, orange, or white and red striped. The beet has a delicious, earthy flavor with a touch of sweetness to it when roasted.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed into soil. Thin to 7cm apart when seedlings are 5cm tall.

plantings.description:
3 1 foot rows of beets planted directly into the soil.

Hopefully they'll go better than last year (in which they did not at all).
I've never been a particularly successful beet grower but this crop seems happy and well formed.
30 'golden Detroit' seeded, germinated ~15 March, thinned 26 March.
8 "early wonder", 8 "golden"

These are in peat pots for now; will be moved to one of the plots if they actually sprout. (This is my first time with beets, I have no idea what will happen.)

All transplanted to the bed by the fence! All but two of the seeds came up - many with more than one plant.

Thinned in late May; and by 'thinned' I mean 'did not have the heart to kill seedlings I had nursed from earliest childhood; attempted to transplant instead'. There are now 20 in this bed, from the original 13; the transplantees are alive but not thriving.
Beetroot, seedlings from Wyvale, not from seed.
Detroit Dark Red, plants, from Merrifield Garden Center.
Detroit Dark Red, seed tape
2 rows third section second half
Burpees Golden Beetroot
There are plants that I 'thinned' from the bed by the fence. Two weeks later they're, uh, still alive? Or at least upright? so I guess they officially get to go in the garden.
Not producing this year. Will replant in another month to see if I can get a fall crop.
Seeds and seedlings around the garden--trying my luck with beets again, although so far not having great luck. They're getting nibbled on and pulled out of the ground.
Red Ace Hybrid.
Bought from Waldeck's.

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: Diggers - Choggia
Diggers - Sugarbeet
My first time with these. Not to mention the chooks'. See how we go...

Mix of heirloom beetroot: Chioggia, Bulls Blood, Golden, White, Blankoma, Mini Gourmet.

Planted in white styrofoam box. 

Eaten by birds.
Diggers Club seedlings from Dickson nursery. Planted into raised garden bed of compost and cow poo.

16 beet plants transplanted from seedlings (in split peat pots, because I was too much of a sissy to actually thin.) Will need to be thinned more in a week or so, though.

Thinned in late May; transplanted some of the thinned plants. There are now 20 in this bed.
"early wonder" variety
"golden" variety
Beetroot, Bull's Blood. Seeds from Phoenix.
Beetroot, rows - continuous crops
2 lines.
Chioga beets.  These got big quite early this year.  I have several more to harvest.  The tops are quite dried up, though.
Flat of Egypt variety
Planted 2015-05-03. 2 rows. Variety: Boltardy.

Forono Beet
Water well during dry season and mulch to reduce weeds.  After they grow 2 inches tall, thin so plants are 4 inches apart.  Eat the thinnings on salads.

Harvest: Dig when roots are 2-3 inches across.  Days to mature: 60
Burpee's Golden beet, from Seed Savers Exchange. Also planted around the squash, will probably harvest for baby greens.
Old Boltardy seeds.
Planted for transplant outdoors. Several have come up at 2 weeks.
Red beetroot

Beetroot Detroit 2 - Crimson Globe
Planted 2 rows in bed 1.  
Row 1 up to the blueberry plant - planted at intervals along dripper line.
Row 4 all the way along dripper line only at outlets.  One each side of the tube.
Interplanted with butternut squash. Some volunteers.
beet blend

Beetroot
Chamomile
Cress
Dill
Onion
Sprinkled a few over 1st 1m2 garden.

2020/3/8: Seeds. Beetroot Chioggia red/white. 6 cells, 4 seeds per cell

2020/3/14: Just beginning to germinate. 

Transplanted into front garden 9/5/20
2 rows planted on the left side, second patch
planted in holes in concrete blocks near snow peas
Beetroot from Woolworths free with $30 purchase
From EcoReality. furthest from house.
Red peppers, marigolds and marjoram interspersed.
Bottom half of the terrace; top row. 4 Gypsy Peppers

California sweet pepper
Black bell pepper
 seeds of the black variety were given by a contact in NI, so far they have not germinated, still in the propagater just in case.
Sweet Rainbow mixed color bell pepper.
Gypsy bell pepper. Elongated. 3-lobed. Light greenish yellow to orange to red. A sweet pepper. Resistant to tobacco mosaic virus.
Yellow bell pepper. Early Sensation.

Won't be planting peppers any more for at least a couple years. Pepper weevils.

Would have gotten more than 1 pepper but the garden center was closed and the hardware store's peppers looked diseased.

EDIT: Added another from the garden center. It is bigger.

EDIT: Got pepper weevils. Will not grow any more peppers for a couple years.
2 from seed, 2 from cutting.
Bell and hot peppers are reasonably productive. Have harvested the first bell pepper, Gypsy, a pale yellow pepper.

Hungarian yellow.
Garden only gets 5-6 hours sun a day so struggle with capsicums. Will be protected by cloche until Nov.

fed, soaped and going well.
Update June 2014: got around 90 peppers over summer, plants still thriving and even a flower or two this morning!

2 each red, yellow and green. The greens died before I figured out to spray water and Epsom salts on them when the leaves are splotchy. Now they're fine with new blossoms and the reds are almost ready!

Merlot Sweet pepper, Jalapeno M Hot pepper, so far only one Merlot fruit. Peppers were overwhelmed by dense tomato foliage. Seedlings purchased online from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com).
actually a paprika-style pepper (banana shaped, red)
mini yellow
Not bell pepper, but can't remember name
Actually Chili - but don't know varieties

@germinated:2015-01-07
Planted in heated seed tray.
King of the North Sweet Bell Pepper, an early pepper suited to the UK, plant is quite short but makes large green peppers quite quickly
4 seedlings split out and repotted on 2015-06-04. Another 1 coming up. 1 not sprouted.

"Golden bell pepper. Light green-deep gold bell pepper. 3-4 lobes, thick walls. Matures in 68 days."

"Green bell pepper. Crunchy green fruits are mostly four-lobed, thick-walled and bloky, turning red at maturity. 60-70 days."

Planted in earthbox on southern balcony, along with small basil and garlic.
3 Sweet Chocolate, transplated 23 June 2015, in multipot
2 Yellow Lunchbox (from purple co-op), 1 Olympus, 1 Islander (from Thorne Farm)

14 Hot pepper, Hybrid Gurney's Primo jalapenos.  Planted 3-25-15 from seed.  Start 3 weeks earlier.  They were little going in. (Extra seeds saved.  There were 25 seeds.)

7 Sweet Pepper, Hybrid sweet Bell Mix.  Yellow/gold, red, purple and orange peppers.

Good production d/t steady rains.  DON'T BURY!!  oops.  Could use more.  Harvesting started early August

19 Wseet Pepper, Hybrid Gurney's Giant II, Can be used green or left on the plant until the skin turns red. Ultimate stuffing peppers.  Maturity 70 days. 

DON'T BURY THEM!  Peppers do not get buried when planting.  Ooops!   About half got peppers on them.
I planted seed in eggshell and am waiting for seed to germinate.
Golden California Wonder Pepper
Horizon Bell Pepper
I'm guessing it's a bell pepper? Of some kind? From Kenny.

Islander, Flavorburst and Antoni Romanian cultivars purchased at MDSW 08 May 2016, from Thorne Farm. Valencia (2), California Wonder, and Superheavyweight purchased from Strosnider's Hardware.

All in hanging pepper pot.
Aji Dulce cultivar pepper (C. chinese). I bought the seed packet on impulse. We'll see how it turns out.
Royal Black pepper cultivar (Capsicum sp.). Should be purple-black.
Yellow and Red bels from Waterpenny Farm at the Takoma Farmer's market
unknown variety
yellow

owner.location: Santa Cruz  de la sierra, Bolivia

plantings.description: in green house
14/11/2017 transplanted to large pots

Golden bell pepper.

"Plan 18-24'' apart in rows 24-36'' apart. Full sun. Harvest at 68 days. F1 hybrid. 4.5''x3.5'' sweet, light green fruits mature to a deep golden yellow. Protect from intense afternoon sun. Best in warm (at least 65F), rich, well drained soil, mulch. Feed when planting and when flowers start."

2014-09-02: Ate first yellow pepper.

2014-10-18: Retired. We got about a dozen peppers - definitely not as many as last year.

Hand-written tag reads "1/11 Pepper, Red beauty".

2013-07-28: First few (of many!) peppers eaten while still green.

2013-08-20: First fully red pepper.

2013-09-22: Eating and giving away lots of bell peppers.

2013-10-07: Picked and pureed the last of the ripe peppers. The plant is still growing new peppers and flowering, but it is also shedding leaves.

2013-12-28: Retired (so we could reuse the pot). The plants had another dozen peppers still on them, in varying stages of ripeness.
Heirloom from trademe. Dolce espana
never sprouted

Paprika lunchbox red - 4 seeds in 4 pots
(Used last year's planting soil with added water)

Paprika Poseidon, 4 seeds, one in each pot
In last year's planting soil.

Paprika Atri's (long, 3 color for ajvar)
One seed in a pot, with last year's planting soil.
Sweet Pepper, Carnival Blend seeds from Burpee. Seeds bought in 2017.

Pepper Etiuda
100% germination by 17/4/2020
Being hardened off in open air daily from 17/4/2020 ready for potting on

attributes.name: Pumpkin
attributes.description: Pumpkins are squash cultivars that are round to oval in shape with thick, slightly ribbed skin that varies from deep yellow to orange in color. Their flesh ranges from yellow to gold and has large seeds. Like other members of the Cucurbitaceae family, they grow on sprawling vines. Different varieties of pumpkins are grown for food or decoration.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors (and transplant outside after seedlings are hardened off) or outdoors

plantings.description: Self sprouted from the location of the old compost bin.
Musquee de Provence
Sprouted underneath an orchid; inside in a pot on the table.
sugar
Pumpkin started from seed. If they survive, I will transplant them into the community garden by the corn -- it will make it into a Three Sister milpa.
Pumpkin started from seed. 27 July 2013 -- transplanted into flowerbed because of water requirements were getting a bit much with the 95+ weather.
Potimarron heirloom variety, in a root pouch pot with a soda-bottle greenhouse for rain protection.
Jap

butternut
Attempting to Grow up trellis's
Potimarron from Diggers.
Cinderella pumpkins
Jack-o-lantern variety.  I planted these a bit late.  The spot gets hot in the afternoon.  I hope it is enough sun for these.  The kids love to grow pumpkins.
Mix of queensland blue, butternut pumpkins and spaghetti squash. Key purpose is covering / shading soil and mulch over summer, prior to planting fruit trees in winter.
Planted Japanese and butternut pumpkins and Lebanese Cucumber seeds.
Various types.

Raised seeds in pots then planted in various locations. 
Harvested one tiny butternut after about six months and a small butternut after about 9 months. They just sat there forever, but we waited for the stem to dry and they tasted good :)
Self seeded from compost. Harvested one big pumpkin at New Year and one medium sized pumpkin in March 2015.
Climbing beans up cone teepee
Orca beans
Ojo de cabra bean
6 bean seedlings from Bunnings. They got scorched and 4 died.
Seedlings from Bunnings. Slow to grow.
Doing OK, but I planted later than usual this season, decided I would wait till after the frosts, which I never do, and now I am not getting the abundance I normally have.
Purple Queen cultivar bush bean from Bontanical Interests seed company
Cheroke Wax bush bean (phaselous vulgaris) from Bontanical Interests seed company
Blue Lake 274 cultivar bush bean from Bontanical Interests seed company
Another 2 bush bean seedlings transplanted in one peat pot!
2 bush bean plants from the same peat pot. I should have either thinned or split but was too much of a coward to do either so we shall see how they grow right next to each other.
Medinah, direct sow
Blue Lake pole beans raised bed one.
These were slow to come up from seed, but when they finally came up, they came up fast, so I transplanted them during a break in the week's rain.
A couple of varieties of bush beans (provider, cherokee wax) planted in weekly batches to (in theory) give me some succession when it comes to picking the crops, rather than a glut.

These are yellow bush beans. Starting in peat pots to see what happens.

All but one of the six seeds I planted sprouted and have been put in the ground! One pot left, with one runty plant and one un-sprouted seed, to see what happens.

Pole Bean. Kentucky Wonder.

June 3: No sign of sprouts. I am going to dig down and see if the seeds have turned to mush from too much rain.
French beans on wigwam at bottom of garden, with compost pile in centre
Planted alongside the steps to the top of the terrace. Not sure how many plants, to be honest--just sorta popped some seeds in and we'll see what happens.
red/scarlet runner bean plant. The trellis is in the closet right now, but once these sprout & get a few inches, they'll be moved outside to climb to their hearts' content.
Stuck 'em in peat pots, since squirrel's eat 'em otherwise.  Half bush bean, half climbing.
broad beans in centre raised bed - 20 Karmazyn + 10 Sutton
King Purple Climbing Bean

Broad beans have gone in during various plantings.
Dwarf green beans, have various plantings in the veg table.
Runner Beans, growing in bean, pots at the front of the house for the first time this year, along with-
Yellow french bean, climber and
Purple french beans, and of course
Berlotti Beans, all at the front of the property.

Bush beans. Green, yellow and purple varieties.

June 3: Not a sprout has appeared from any of the plantings. I suspect too much rain has ruined the seeds. Plan to replant.
Dwarf beans which I have had a lot of success with before. Grown from seed saved from last season.
Variety bush beans, most have green pods but some have yellow, white/purple speckled, and purple pods.  They make delicious "green" beans!
Planted more Linguo di Fuoco Borlotto beans, mostly among the corn.
scarlet runner bean, var. "painted lady improved" from Seed Savers Exchange, started in styrofoam egg carton. Rated at 68 days.

Black beans just planted from bag of beans from the corner store.

It had some beans! They turned purple!!!

Planted from seed. Beans of undetermined origin. Given to me in an unmarked envelope. Possibly magic beans. 

Planted next to arugula.
Saved seeds from previous year
indoor
took a cutting from the primary bean plant just to see if i could start another with no additional help.

Scarlet runner beans -- Phaseolus coccineus -- started to replace the string beans that are beginning to die in the left flowerbed. 31 July 2013 -- transplanted to flowerbed, because 2 days after sprouting, they're over a foot tall...
Armenda Ward's Bottom, greasy beans from Kentucky. Planted with our corn.
Bush beans, planted yearly. This year three varieties -- wax, Royal Burgundy (purple) and green. Have already harvested 6+ lbs, and production is just getting started.
Broad Windsor fava beans, for overwintering and a spring crop.
Purple organic bush-bean

Pole green beans, planted in 1x3 behind the zucchini. Had to plant twice as only two came up the first time.

Will definitely provide vertical strings next time, horizontal is too messy.

There were some pole beans seedlings (Kentucky wonder) at the garden center when I was buying peppers and eggplants and herbs. They were cheap so even though I doubt they'll grow, I figured it was worth a try. 

EDIT: They grew well, but I did not like the beans, they were stringy and even though I followed the internet's instructions to remove the strings, they were still stringy. Will not grow Kentucky wonder again.
3 rows broad beans

Beans of unknown origin, given to me in an unmarked envelope. 

Turned out to be long beans of some variety. Horrible tasting and the bean plants themselves attempted to take over everything
Planted by Ollie and Sare Sare

Late frost killed most seedlings, replanted afterward. The few that survived the frost are still producing well, having resisted the depredations of an insect pest that made lace of the leaves. The younger plants were hit harder by the bugs and produced less, but still respectably. Variety was cherokee trail black beans.
In bean bed (2 per cane).
bush
French
raised bed hugelkultur planter
The  snake beans are growing up chicken wire stapled to the picket fence, doing well so far, but the neighbors dog likes to chew off any shoots that come through.
Anellino Giallo
Bush bean seedlings via the Community Garden.
Purple climbing beans
Scarlet runner bean seeds zach gave me from the anarchist farming festival
The beans harvested from existing plants are much more likely to sprout.

Broad Beans

Planted 2 beans per hole, on East side of house, gets shade from about 2-3pm onwards
French beans. Planed indoors and translated outside on the 18th May 2015. Against rear garden wall and staked.

Bush Bean, Early Contender
After seedlings grow 4-6 inches tall, thin to 6 inches apart.  
Don't cultivate or harvest when plants are wet as disease can spread this way.  
Harvest regularly to encourage continued production
Produces 6-8 inch pods. Favorite for processing.
Days to maturity: 49

Picked on July 8.  Lots of beans the first picking.  Enough for 3 farm meals for sure.  Long, green.  NICE.  I planted one row, about 8 feet long.  No plans to freeze, just eat fresh.

11 dwarf beans; 2 white. 

Finally transplanted these out! From http://www.growstuff.org/plantings/spadix-seed-trays-bean/

6 November: Took the collars off a few days ago. All looking okay - one has lost a leaf from high winds. Hoping they do okay as beans prefer direct sowing.
I planted seed in eggshell and am waiting for seed to germinate. (green bean)

Five groups of 2 seeds each, at the base of six-foot spiral poles to climb.  
Variety Pole bean, "Gold of Bacau"
Concador Yellow Bush Haricots Verts
Provider bush bean
From seed, not seedling, unlike the rest. All seeds in one spot - will have to thin if they all make it.

var. Royalty Purple Pod bush bean
Phaseolus vulgaris. Seed source Southern Exposure Seed Exchange.

"52 days. Meaty and flavorful, slightly curved 5 inch purple pods." 

Pods blanch to green when cooked.

Dwarf beans - mostly standard, 2 white. Sprouted in hot water cupboard, planted in punnets in seed raising mix by 10 October 2015.

17 October: all have germinated, 8 have emerged from the soil and are fully upright..

22 October: planted out into bottom patch strip. All looking good on the 25th!

I found this seedling growing in one of my orchid planters.  I pulled it off and proceeded to plant it in the ground.

Pigeon peas are a source of nitrogen for the soil.  They are very rich in iron and used as a meat substitute.  They can be harvested when green or dry.  A variety of dishes can be made from this legume.

The bushes can be used for a trellis for climbers such as cucumber, loofahs, or others.  They can serve as shade for other crops growing underneath them.
Climbing green bean. Planted under sunflowers to grow up fence.
this are red/pink beans.
Pois-fve Lalibert

attributes.name: Mint
attributes.description: Mint is a perennial herb with a distinctive taste. It's stems are square-shaped and it has pink, purple, or white flowers. Peppermint, ginger mint, and large apple mint are hybrids of mint. Mint is often grown in pots to prevent it from overtaking the garden with its invasive, spreading rhizome root structure. It's leaves are most aromatic before the plant flowers and can be used fresh, dried, or frozen. Mint's strongly scented leaves confuse the pests of carrots, tomatoes, alliums, and brassicas, and deter flea beetles.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors or outside

plantings.description: Mint inna pot.
In a planter on the porch in the afternoon sun.
Using it as ground cover b/c it's tenacious
chocolate and ricola mint in the japanese willow bed, spear and apple mint in the birdfeeder bed, ginger mint in a hanging basket, all several years old.

owner.location: East Coast, Central Vancouver Island, BC, Canada

plantings.description: chocolate mint, in a cement mixing tub I prepared last year with Leaf Gro.
spearmint.
Garden mint, and Moroccan mint for tea.  Lovely and survived the awful winter and spring here.

Mint in a little plastic pot on the shadiest bit of the porch.
Moved to wooden planter box. Still not flourishing. What is wrong with my mint?  :(
Oregon mint is the best!
Three mints now: Grapefruit, Lemon, and Spearmint. As with lemon balm, they are all planted outside of raised beds and allowed to propogate at will. The spearmint is by far the most useful.
24/1/2015 - died right back. Appears to be reviving!

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: Sprigs picked from outside a neighbour's house where mint is growing through their front fence.
Near the carport. It's quite shady there.
Rescued in an extremely sorry state, most of it died. One shoot currently alive and kicking, so I have hopes.
another companion plant, this is planted down next to the frog pond.
Herb - Chocolate Mint

Date approximate. Planted in a container on a north-facing balcony. 

After an OMG-too-much mint experience, we resisted growing it for years, but finally gave in. We do our best to neglect it, and it still grows like a weed.

2015-01-25: Took a few cuttings in the hopes of planting one in a smaller pot and then retiring the original larger plant.

2015-05-16: Finally got cuttings that are doing well. Working on retiring the mint as fast as we can eat it.
Grown via hydroponics in a auto pot
Planted 5? seeds in a 20cm diameter pot
Potted
Died of lack of water, I think.
Aphids! They are my bane. Always attacking my mint. I find squishing them the most natural/cheap method... but they seem to reappear from time to time.
Christmas present from Rachel. Sitting on the windowsill.
Planted probably 2 years ago. Self sustaining.

attributes.name: Corn
attributes.description: Corn is a large grain plant, or tall grass, first domesticated about 10,000 years ago by indigenous peoples in Southern Mexico. The leafy stalk produces ears after pollination. Depending on the variety, the corn can be eaten fresh, or dried and ground into cornmeal.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors

plantings.description: Painted Mountain Corn - seeds from TerritorialSeed.com
Seedlings very palatable to squirrels and rabbits. The one stalk that survived produced a single very tasty ear.

Seneca Red Stalker variety. Survived to produce ears but had to harvest early due to squirrel depredations. Ears currently drying. Stalks and leaves relished by goats, plants are gorgeous. Recommend this variety if you want a flour corn that's also a stunning ornamental and yields good livestock fodder.
Corn in Ohio. Duh.

Abenaki corn, three sisters method.

Also, Crows suck.
This is hybrid field corn we are growing as an experiment, never tried it before!
Hybrid sweet corn, for our own eating.

Hybrid field corn.

We wanted to see how corn does here without irrigation.

Pennsylvanian Butter-Flavored Popcorn from Southern Seed Savers. Starting this inside, but will move to community garden. 9 June 2013 -- moved to Right flowerbed among the beans -- given them some scaffolding. 24 july 2013 -- tassels and ears are appearing!
26 ears set, seems to be growing nicely. Corn should be ready within the next month.
Grew the plants from seed in the greenhouse. Have planted them out in an 8'x4' raised bed. In Scotland. Average temperature just now is 16deg. Am an optimist.
Tama Flint from the USDA's GRIN service. This is a variety grown by the Meskwaki tribe of Tama, Iowa, a tribe that used to live in this area 170+ years ago.
Planted along the right side, 10 inches apart, in 1x3 Doing well!
Glass Gem decorative flint corn. About 8 feet tall, end of August. Several bouquet (split) ears. Purchased from an eBay Seller.

Pennsylvanian Butter-Flavored Popcorn from Southern Seed Savers. Started this in topsoil bought with Holli's help. Didn't think much would happen, but the plants are growing well. Add green bean seedling among the corn plants. Maybe I'll get some squash and make it into a true milpa plot with all of the three sisters.
7/10/14 - all seedlings have now germinated.
Sweet Corn seed, Goodman seeds from Formosa.

Golden Bantam, Country Gentleman, and Seneca Red Stalker planted. Crop severely damaged by Japanese beetles. Ran guineas in the area and replanted, but was too late in season for a crop. Goats relished stalks at least.
Planted amongst the lawn on mounds in rows, first row has been nibbled by ducklings
Bull's Blood flint corn & Bicolor Hybrid sweet corn. Will transplant when started
Strawberry popcorn from Baker Creek Heirloom Seeds

32 golden bantam improved corn
16 martian jewels sweet corn
16 double red sweet corn
16 painted hill corn
16 argent sweet corn
8 maize morado corn
8 teosinte
4 teosinte-corn f1 hybrid
4 pod corn

attributes.name: Rhubarb
attributes.description: Rhubarb is a perennial herbaceous plant in USDA Zones 4-8. It cannot be harvested from in the first year of planting. It has large green leaves that are poisonous and thick, red-green stalks that are edible raw or cooked. It's stalks have a strong, tart taste and are commonly used in strawberry-rhubarb pies.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant crowns or direct seed indoors

plantings.description: Because the old one died when I transplanted it.
Planted 4. One (the one that gets the least moisture) seems to have died. Bugs (probably box elder bugs) are eating holes in the leaves.

Settling in well, and the chooks are leaving it alone!

Update 2013-09-21: growing well, something eating the leaves; got a drenching with soapy water today. Fingers crossed.

Planted two varieties of Rhubarb into large pots. They're just starting to send out shoots with small leaves. Looking forward to lots of yummy rhubarb treats in the future.

Also accidentally brought some seeds, which apparently take 2-3 years before they're productive. :-(

4 "Victoria" variety rhubarb plants, from seedlings purchased at the CERES nursery. Potted into 8" pots with a mix of potting mix and a couple of trowels-ful of compost.  Gave them a quick seaweed-emulsion watering.  Hopefully they like it.
Two large containers with 3 plants in each
Divided and replanted old rhubarb
from BCFTA

attributes.description: The apple is a deciduous tree in the Rose family grown for it's sweet fruit. The apple originated in Central Asia and has spread across the world. There are now over 7,500 cultivars bred for a variety of climates and characteristics. Apples are propagated through grafting because seeds do not breed true.
attributes.sowing_method: Bare root tree

plantings.description: Redfields apple, grafted onto m7 rootstock.
Double grafted tree: redfields at the top, M9 in the middle for sturdy trunk, M111 at the bottom for vigorous rooting. Mounded dirt up around it to surpress suckering of the M111.
Egremont Russet mid-season
Tydeman's Late Orange.  Late fruiting variety.  Supposed to be on dwarf rootstock, but still growing rather big.
Laxton's Fortune apple tree
vv

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: An apple tree that has been there since before our move into the house. It didn't give any fruit last year but apparently that was a very bad year for apples all round.
Honey Crisp.  Arrived today from Gurney.  We dug deep holes and filled it with soil from Ma's swing patio.  Need to fertilize in 3 months.  It came with the trees.
Leprechaun- Dwarf green apple
Pinkabelle - dwarf Pink Lady
Queen Cox self-fertile, planted against south-facing wall to train into espalier.
Seems to be coping with the clay soil.

Apple - Dwarf Dorsett Golden
Apple - Dwarf Tropic Sweet

Planted very close, intention is to keep them close cropped and small.
We have a  jonathan and a something else which I cant remember at the moment and I can remember when we planted them.
Pengaled on M25 - cider-apple, no fruit yet, healthy growth
Honey Crisp, Fuji, and Gravenstein

Can't remember varieties, both on dwarfing rootstock, planted in smaller borders
(planting date very approximate, more likely highly inaccurate)
transparent variety.  tastes insipid, but the half-fallen tree creates a beautiful shaded area for woodland plants.

owner.location: East Coast, Central Vancouver Island, BC, Canada

plantings.description: Rosemary Russett on M25 - 1 year old maiden, some blossoms this year, seems to be growing well so far
Braeburn and Macoun
I have one Bramley, cooking apple.  Plus I also have 1 braburn, which is an eating apple.  Both are in pots, and fruited for the first time on 2012
Granny Smith to go with an unknown type of Apple already planted
Keeper Melrose, eating/cooking Alkemene and Dayton
sops-in-wine on M25 - purple leaves & dark pink blossoms. Should be a cooker / cider, but no fruit yet (was planted as a 1 year old maiden)

Granny Smith
Bought from Lena's the day before. The pink lady was flowering and it seemed a pity to waste the opportunity, so we got iteven though it's not really the right time to be planting trees.
It's in the northern most row, closest to the path.

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: This apple tree was here when I moved in.  I have no idea what kind it is (yet); it might be a crabapple.

UPDATE: The rootstock lives! I can't believe it recovered because when the tree died I stopped watering. It put out a very vigorous shoot, and I intend to either let it grow as a crabapple tree, or re-graft. It also put out a sucker, which I planted in a pot and it rooted.

UPDATE: Died to the rootstock during the hot spell last year.

EDIT: Fair number of blooms this year (2014). Doubt I'll get fruit this year though nothing's impossible. Two of the grafts seem to have died, but the other three are looking good.

Not actually sure the exact planting date, sometime in January. Part of the new orchard! Apple "fruit salad" tree. It leafed out and has had 1 bloom (of course I don't expect fruit this year). I'm trying to decide, should I fertilize this year or wait until next year? I did mulch with compost/aged manure.
Bloody Ploughman on M25 - should be an eater, but no fruit yet. Showing signs of canker attack, but very vigorous growth so will hopefully survive!
Howgate Wonder on M26 - mid-late season large cooker/eater, bears well but has suffered from canker
Scarlet sentinel columnar apple.  From Raintree Nursery.
North pole columnar apple.  From Raintree Nursery.

varieties
Jonagold on Supporter 4 rootstock (Hess Nursery)
2 Black Oxford on Bud 9 dwarf stock ( Fedco Trees )
Northern Spy on Bud 9 dwarf stock (  Fedco Trees ) 
Cortland on Bud 9 dwarf stock (  Fedco Trees ) 
Honeycrisp on Bud 9 dwarf stock (  Fedco Trees )

1 - Jonagold on Supporter 4 rootstock, moved from back of yard. Grafted 2010, originally planted from pot F2014.  Source Hahn Nursery.
2 - Black Oxford on Bud 9 dwarf stock - source Fedco Trees. bareroot. Planted 2015 & 2017.
1 - Northern Spy on Bud 9 dwarf stock - source Fedco Trees. bareroot. Planted 2015.
1 - Honeycrisp on Bud 9  - source Fedco Trees. bareroot. Planted 2017.

Pink Lady.
Dug up from the old house, where it hadn't been very successful in the 12 years or so it had been there. Now planted in the northern most row of the orchard, second from the path. Cygnet's placenta is planted under it, because he 'likes red'.
Pink Lady Well, transplanted into a pot in 2013, but put in the ground in about 2002.

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: dwarf
2 Akane apples, 1 Liberty apple.
Dukat dill. Planted downhill from boulder, below carrots. Shallow soil.
1 pot

Dill in punnet from Bunnings.

Planted with Italian Parsley.
Gets afternoon sun.  I think it would prefer full sun but it seems to be doing okay.
fernleaf variant, in large blue pot #1.

owner.location: East Coast, Central Vancouver Island, BC, Canada

plantings.description: Planted from seed next to our basil.
wintersown container
Dukat
two clay seedballs. a few of the sprouts got nibbled away, but some remain for now.
Going to seed quickly, but hoping it will reseed itself like all the other annual herbs have so far.
Died in 2 weeks
Pre-germinated on wet paper towel for ~5 days. Already growing quite quickly.

I was planting cucumber so I thought I'd plant dill at the same time.  One of the cucumbers is in a huge recycling tub, so I put the cucumber kind of toward one end, and the dill at the other.  I also planted some in a smaller pot.

Periodically sprinkled dill seeds in a bunch of pots (shared with other plants), on both north and south facing balcony.

2014-08-10: Harvested most of the dills seed in the last few weeks. Planted a few seeds which have sprouted.

2014-10-05: The new round of dill dried out sometime in Sept. Harvested the last of the dill seeds. Replanted some.

2014-11-15: We have new dill.
Dill plant from Takoma Park farmers market
planted last year's seed.
Duka Leafy
Dill seeds from Farm Fresh To You CSA

I didn't think the dill had reseeded itself, so I bought one small plant.  But now I see there are a number of sprouts where last year's dill was.  This plant died, though.  It was eaten by aphids, oddly.

Currently in small pots on the north-facing balcony.

Previous attempts at growing dill have all failed. but so far so good.

2013-09-01: Succumed to scale bugs and retired.

attributes.name: Cauliflower
attributes.description: Cauliflower is a vegetable in the Brassicaceae family. The solid, firm head resembles that of broccoli and is usually white, but can also be yellow, purple, or green in color. Like broccoli, it sits atop a stalk. The head is wrapped in thick leaves that begin to open when the plant is ready for harvest. All cauliflower does best in cool weather.

plantings.description: sowed seeds indoors under grow lights 2/10

attributes.description:
Eggplants commonly are egg-shaped with glossy black skin, but can come in a variety of other shapes and colors. They can be white, yellow, and pale to deep purple. Some are as small as goose eggs. The 'Rosa Bianca' cultivar is squat and round, while Asian cultivars can be long and thin. Eggplant stems are often spiny and their flowers range from white to purple. 

Their flesh is generally white with a meaty texture and small seeds in the center. They are delicious grilled, roasted, in soups and stews, and breaded and fried.
attributes.sowing_method: Sow seeds indoors and transplant out, or plant nursery seedlings

plantings.description: Ping tung long asian eggplant.
"Early long purple" variety
1 "Princess", 6 "Black Beauty". The Princess has grown 2 tiny eggplants, the Black Beauties have lots of leaves and flowers but no fruit.
Little Prince
Planted two seedling eggplants
Japanese eggplant
long japanese variety, in green sub-irrigation container #1.

owner.location: East Coast, Central Vancouver Island, BC, Canada

plantings.description: Planted in paper pots.
Planted late from seed directly into the ground. None but one popped up (unsurprising due to massive amounts of rain). Doesn't seem to be growing, though.
Got one!
Heirloom Rosa Bianca seeds, a striped pink and white variety.
Gretel cultivar -- white eggplant
Planted indoors in potting soil in egg cartons and small pots. A hybrid Asian variety.
finger
Black beauty.
early long purple
... flowers keep dropping off. One left, hope it holds on!

**Variety:** long purple

3/22: started seeds indoors
Little Prince container eggplant from Renee's Garden seed company
Aubergine ronde de Valence
Yellow Cherry Tomato, Purple Kale, Black Zucchini, Parsley, Eggplant, Yellow Squash, Green Beans, Green Onion
last year's seeds - we will see how it goes
Yasakanaga, Hybrid (Solanum melongena)
They were there when I moved in.

two plants about 60 cm apart within dripper lines 
and installed plant guards ,to be removed in a couple of weeks

attributes.name: Snow Pea
attributes.description: Snow Peas are a variety of pea that can be eaten whole in the pod while still unripe. The flat, sweet, crisp pods are eaten fresh and added to salads and stir-fries. Like other peas, Snow Peas do best in cooler weather and benefit from inoculation just before planting. Some varieties require trellising. If trellising, increase row spacing to 1.2 m.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors, thin to 10cm

plantings.description: McKenzie Asian Vegetables brand. Planted in corner farther away from house, uphill.

Old seed, not sure if still viable. Sprouting on paper towel in hot water cupboard.

5 November: A couple did germinate. Forgot to water and they got dried out too much and started going mildewy. Composted them.
Bought at Home Depot.
This is an experiment. The ground is still hard from the colder than average winter so I started them in old containers. We'll see how it goes.
Planted along half fence.
Planted between Purple Peas.
variety for pea vines

Finally got the bed by the trellis up and running. I planted these closer together than the instructions said, because I had a lot and ehhh why not.  If they all come up I'll thin them a bit (the shoots are tasty anyway, right?)
Two big pots full, Oregon Giant "Snowman" variety.
3 tubs of 12 snowpeas each, with stakes set tripod style for them to climb up.

only have 7 weeks before our chook rotation hits so am hoping to get some fruit in that time.

Have germinated and pushing through soil.
Okay, so apparently these are a winter crop and I didn't realise it. Oops!
Winter plantings of snowpeas in the Greenhouse

owner.location: 104 Crompton Street Soldiers Hill Ballarat Victoria Australia

plantings.description: Planted along our trellis, with halved toilet paper rolls to try to protect them from the slaters.
Put in the plastic greenhouse until 11 October, then in their main pot.
Eaten by critters.

Doggedly trying to grow snow peas after many failures outdoors.
Update: failed again. No harvests.
4 are under mason jars. 1 is not because I lost track of it. It's a bit late for planting, but we'll see.
