attributes.name: Sunflower
attributes.description: Sunflowers are large flowers with bright to deep yellow ray florets surrounding a large circular grouping of disc florets that mature into seeds. Sunflowers are grown for ornamental purposes, cut flowers, or their edible seeds. They can reach heights of 300cm or more.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors after last frost in groups of 2-3, thin to 1 plant when true leaves appear

plantings.description: Marigolds planted around North and East side of garden.  They had gotten wet in the rain 1 week before planting.
One remaining and doing pretty well

I germinated them from seed I bought from my local community garden. They were big enough to plant after two weeks! One has passed due to steam rot (can't remember what it is called- shot up too fast).
Made a large plot for a living wall.

Mixed heirloom "fire" sunflowers and mammoth sunflowers.

So far all the mammoth plants have died.  Most of the heirloom plants are hanging on, although they are not nearly as tall as their wild cousins, and have yet to produce blooms.
Var. "Titan" from Seed Savers Exchange, in clear egg carton. Rated at 75 days.
1 propagator tray of red sunflower seeds from Thailand.
I was worried they wouldn't have enough sun indoors, but they outpaced even the super-speedily-growing basil.
"Geraldton Giant" sunflowers using seeds from Yilgarn. Hoping they'll semi-naturalise in the drylands garden. Planted with za'atar oregano and purple carrots near the female pistachio tree.

owner.location: Thornlie, Perth, Western Australia (southern suburbs, Bassendean sands)

plantings.description: A mixed variety mostly for show and birds.  Many sizes and colors. Variety pack from seed savers. Planted along fence line. Slow start this year as something was eating them, but they have recovered now. Good for late season bees.
two varieties: italian white, and teddy bear
Volunteer black oil sunflower. Thrived and provided excellent bean pole. Saved head for next year's seed.
I feed birds, so we get uncountable volunteer sunflowers

Tossed a heap of seed around, hopefully some of it will take.  Two different types -- Sunfola (tall and yellow) and evening sun (shorter and reddish).  Hopefully if I get a few growing I can get them to self-seed thereafter by just tossing seed around in the right areas.
Seems like those didnt make it. As those seeds came from last year harvest, were they viable ?
Either Red Sun or Edible Seed cultivar -- can't remember which seeds sprouted before I transplanted them. 27 July 2013 -- the big one is a Red Sun, and flowering beautifully.

calendula sown by seed outdoors- so "how many" is wild card.
Seed is a mix of saved seed and purchased seed.
Ken's large seeds from his 2m plant. Didn't germinate.
Zinnia seeds from last year planted around garden next to fence.

Burpee sunflower, Chianti Hybrid.  Red
4-5 feet
Zinnia seeds from last year planted around garden next to fence.

2021-06-09 : Three out from earth, will wait a bit before transplant.

2021-06-29 : The three of them have true leaves the size of the young ones, replanted them in the bigger container. Worried by the small root development.
I planted seed in eggshell and am waiting for seed to germinate.

Black seed var.

2021-06-21 : Doesnt seem to grow. Pruned out two seedling looking sick (Weak seedlings, couldnt form leaves)
Mammoth Sunflower seedling from Waterpenny farm
eaten by slugs / trampled by felines.
20200520 : Temperature outdoor seems fine (>16C), put it on the balcony. The flower bud appeared and will soon open
eaten by snails
eaten by snails

Buried some seeds, will select afterward

2021-04-17 : First seedlings appearing (survived freeze). Will transplant some on nearby grounds and keep only one.

2021-04-21 : Thinned to one seedling. Planted remaining one in public allotment

2021-04-26 : True leaves appearing.

2021-05-11 : Suddenly became soft. Not sure of the cause, probably the lack of sun or high humidity of the soil those last few day as temperatures seem fine.

2021-05-20 : Seedling looks back to life, but suffers from plant rust. Pruning may be required.

2021-05-28 : Definitely dead.

attributes.name: Blueberry
attributes.description: Perennial flowering plants with sweet, indigo-colored berries. Blueberry plants are usually erect, prostrate shrubs that range in height from 10cm to 4m high, depending on the cultivar.
attributes.sowing_method: Plant plants into soil or pots.

plantings.description: Another crop lost to lack of water.
Approximate number of bushes, planted at different times since Spring 2009, now starting to form into a hedge bordering our strawberry patch - as intended.
Two blueberries live next to the orchard (although we may move them this year), and a couple back near the vegetable garden.
Four separate varieties
Three varieties, early, middle and late season.
2 high bush, 3 low bush? have to check.

Planted 4 different sorts to maximise the harvest period.  Bought from Ceres nursery and the 4th type is a very small stick of an unknown type.  I've left the flowers on the plants, so I might even get blueberries this summer.

The Sunshine Blue is closest to the water meter, then the Brigitta, then the Highbush and finally the unlabelled stick that I was given for free.

Top hat blueberry (dwarf).  Planted 2012.  Purchased from U-District Farmers Market.  Had some blueberries last year!  Doesn't look like i'll have any this year (suspected culprit: i forgot to fertilize this spring).  I definitely need to prune the bush this year.

2014:  Moved to Cobweb Cottage.
Flowered prolifically in early spring then suffered in Sep-Oct when we went away for 2 weeks. Now lots of new growth and berries established. Grown in acid loving potting mix.
Found 2 leaf hoppers attacking my blueberry bushes
Miniature
Duke variety of blueberries. Planted next to our parking area .

Morning sun, afternoon shade, evening add'l sun in summer.
Underneath a white pine that builds rich acidic soil.

highbush var. "Patriot"

1 in the spillway
1 in the bed above
Bought from Stark Bros. Patriot blueberry.
Bought from Stark Bros. Pink lemonade blueberry.
There are many varieties of blueberry, I believe I have 2  x the "highbush" variety

attributes.description: Cabbage is a member of the Brassica family and related to kale, broccoli, brussels sprouts, and cauliflower. It's dense, layered heads grow on stalks and are surrounded by looser outer leaves. It's leaves can be green, white, or purple in color, and smooth or crinkly in texture. Depending on the variety, the head can be round, oblong, or flat. Cabbage prefers cooler temperatures and is best planted in the spring or fall.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant seedlings outside after hardening off.

attributes.name: Swiss Chard
attributes.description: Swiss Chard is a leafy green vegetable in the Beet family. The thick stems come in a variety of colors including white, pink, red, yellow, orange, and pale green. Chard has large, crinkly leaves with distinctive veins. The leaves and stems are edible and high in nutrients. Swiss chard can be eaten raw, sauted, baked, or steamed.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors or outdoors. Transplant seedlings after hardening off.

plantings.description: Bright LIghts swiss chard. Planted downhill from boulder, below okra. Very shallow soil.
Between boulder and stairs. Burpee's brand rainbow mix.
Mixed chard varieties. Rainbow.
Will it germinate? WHO KNOWS.
Rainbow Lights variety.
I'm hoping to have these ready to plant in late February, maybe early March, when our cool season greens are supposed thrive.
Wintersowing some Swiss chard in a milk jug.

attributes.name: Rainbow Chard
attributes.description: Rainbow Chard is grown from a seed mix that contains chard cultivars that have pink, yellow, orange, red, and white stems. Both the leaves and stems are edible and are delicious in salads, sauted, and baked. Chard is related to beets.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors or outdoors. Transplant seedlings outside after hardening off.

plantings.description: wintersown container
Square tray - no separations
Planted before last winter, still going strong.
"rainbow beet".

Threw in some old seed collected from plants between the multicoloured beet I have now. Not sure if viable.

15 December: It was viable! I have clumps coming up; it looks like they may all be red ones.

26 Dec: Looks like all four seeds from some clusters germinated as they are tightly clumped. Pricked out some of them and moved some (at least 10) to empty spaces in the patch. They are all red.
something is eating this

Planted 12 seeds in seed tray in upper greenhouse
Plant 12 more in another two-three weeks
Grows well in Hawaii
silverbeet
In amongst the agapanthus.
All over one corner of the front garden between the fence and the driveway - between the roses, the pelargoniums, the lavendar and the honeysuckle.
Bought some seedlings, nothing fancy. Just wanted to put something in the garden bed to stop the weeds from taking over again, but I am looking forward to some pretty salads, too.
Some volunteer nasturtiums from a friend's yard, transplanted to my own. Will use for salad prettiness!
White nasturtium seeds planted below the metal trellis. Coming up lovely!
2 varieties. Red nasturtiums and yellow/orange trailing nasturtiums.
with heliotrope in window box in front of paramour's window.

owner.location: East Coast, Central Vancouver Island, BC, Canada

plantings.description: 2 varieties -- cherry red and Alaska
Planted to fill gaps and the lovely plants turn up in various places bring bright joy to all who see them.
Yellow varietal

Packet of nasturtium seeds (Alaska) planted in newly rejuvenated soil under old, well-established lemon tree. Seeds from last year's plants also spread. Seedlings appeared in April, first flowers in June. Nasturtium intended as a) seasonal protective groundcover for lemon tree; b) flowers to amuse toddlers; c) source of seedpods to pickle as capers (delicious).

owner.location: Thornlie, Perth, Western Australia (southern suburbs, Bassendean sands)

plantings.description: Planted in a hanging container, 1 from seed, 2 as seedlings bought at Benkhe's, Empress of India cultivar
soaked a handful of seeds from Skud, chucked them in a big terracotta pot with home brand potting mix.
Fothergill seeds...had trouble sprouting these last year but going to give it a second go...
Empress India (as red flowers)

Various spots: in the terracotta pot near the clothesline, and starting to pop up in the compost heap near the shed, and even in the lawn along the back fence.  Fine by me... I love nasturtiums and would be happy to have them all over the place, especially if it means I don't have to mow.
Tossed a heap of seed around, hopefully some of it will take.  I've had a rough time getting nasturtium established, which is ridiculous!
From the Takoma Park farmers market. Separated 2 of 3 seedlings from the same pot. I "borrowed" a seemingly abandoned large clay pot from the for-sale apt building next door to plant these...
One wool hanging container on the porch, and the rest distributed in the plant leftover dirt by my apartment building
middle
Self seeding everywhere and this is wonderful
Mixed three varieties together, and planted a row across the front, on either side of the hydrangea.  There may be too many slugs in this bed for these.  We'll see.

Mixed three packets of different varieties (trailing, mounding, and some with variegated leaves) together and made a long row of these along the back of the house.  It may be too hot for these, ultimately.
11 nov 2017 -> transplated into south garden
Replacement for an old thyme plant that outgrew itself. They do need replacing every so often of course.

attributes.description:
The leek is a vegetable, a cultivar of Allium ampeloprasum, the broadleaf wild leek. The edible part of the plant is a bundle of leaf sheaths that is sometimes erroneously called a stem or stalk. Historically, many scientific names were used for leeks, but they are now all treated as cultivars of A. ampeloprasum. The name 'leek' developed from the Anglo-Saxon word "leac". Two closely related vegetables, elephant garlic and kurrat, are also cultivars of A. ampeloprasum, although different in their uses as food. The onion and garlic are also related, being other species of the genus Allium.
Leeks have thick blue-green foliage. The bundle of white leaf sheaths has a mild onion taste and can be blanched, steamed, braised, or grilled and used in soups, stews, omelet fillings, and more. The leaves can be used to make stock.

Plant their leeks in autumn, and they should fatten up in time for winter picking. Plant them early to ensure they have enough time to grow before winter. Leeks take up to six months to mature after transplanting.

Newer cultivars have quicker maturity  three to four months. Maturity is often affected by temperature, available nutrients and water. 

Leeks need a soil that is rich in organic matter. Dig in compost or manure two weeks before planting. Add fertiliser every few weeks
Leeks like aged manure, especially chicken manure, and worm castings, another excellent source of nutrients.

Plant seedlings in full sun, with moist but well-drained deep soil. Raised beds are ideal. Water young plants frequently.

The white part of the leek is edible; the green is not. You can blanch the stems to increase the proportion of stem thats edible and to sweeten the taste. Do this to fully grown leeks. Tie a paper collar around each stem and gently hill the earth up around the stem. Be careful not to get soil between the paper collar and stem as the leek may rot.
As the plants grow, add another collar above the first one and hill up more soil. Be aware that slugs and snails can hide in the paper collars

Harvest the leeks when stems are around 2.5cm in diameter. Dig carefully around the leek and lift with a garden fork. Do not pull, as the leek is likely to break.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed or transplant seedlings

plantings.description: Porvite, Autumn Giant 3, King Richard, Musselburgh, Lyon 2 (Prizetaker) - qty approx.
seeds sown indoors Feb / March 2013, pricked out into modules around May. Varieties: Autumn Giant 3, Porvite & Below Zero. Good crop achieved last year with porvite & below zero

Didn't have a ton of luck with these last year, but oddly enough some seeds from *last year* are suddenly popping up in the main bed.

So, I've begun the wintersowing experiment by putting them in a milk jug, and they'll sit in there until they've grown a bit (and the bed gets its spring tilling).
2 rows at far end of bed
Flowering Chinese leek from Seed Savers Exchange. Started seeds in styrofoam egg carton.
Soliase Blue
Growing leeks from seeds hasn't worked for me in the past, so I bought 12 seedlings from an organic farmer, fingers crossed!
transplanted self seeded leeks
Getting big. Continuing to mulch as necessary. Should be as productive and as long-lasting as previous crop, which was accessible well into the winter.
Second planting.
Three short rows, interplanted with radishes. I put another 20 seedlings into a couple of pots because I didn't have room in the garden yet; hopefully I can find room for them in a little while.
I have never grown leeks before.  Sprouted 4/7/15.

Started seeds indoors. Used food growing method: place seeds in mouth, under tongue for 9 mins; hold in hand and breath over them; hold to celestial bodies for at least 30 seconds; plant with fingers/toes and wait 3 days to water

Planted in earthbox on south-facing balcony.

2014-04-07: Retired most of the leeks (leek soup).

2014-06-06: Retired remaining leeks.

Leek Winter Giant. 6 cells. 

Transplanted to front garden 17/5/20
Bought at co-op, finally transplanted into grow after the groundskeeping crew weedwhacked some of my pepper plants...
one row
A row of lavender bushes along the front of the house.
A Canary Island species by the front fence near the driveway.  The bees love it.
Cuttings planted by older bush.
Medium sized plant in the porch in the afternoon sun.
French Lavendar, 8" plant from the clearance aisle of nursery. As of spring 2013, not dead, but very little growth.

Planted by previous tenants. 

2013-05-06: Thriving, and currently flowering.

Crowded out the mint that was planted alongside it. 
Needs more sun than it gets in the window, so is enjoying a timeshare on the front porch.
Planted out in new bed to the side of the drive, in May.  Have had since tiny seedlings late last year, and have grown them on.
Poor dear is sending up scraggly flowers already. Just repotted into a much bigger home.
I think it's L. dentata, or French lavender. Rooted in water, now moved to small pot.
French lavender, flowering profusely
Hidcote Blue lavender, purchased online from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com). This is another container planting. Small but beautiful, giving flowers as of mid-July.
Tiny lavendar plant from the Takoma Park co-op.
New lavender since the previous ones died. Middle of the right hand box.
Died, probably of lack of water
Christmas present
20200529 : Many flower buds, plant looks good even though I may over-water it
Provencal sweet cultivar
So awsome... It grows back really fast and I continually pick at it.
Silverbeet 'perpetual'. Green Harvest seeds.
Used organic seeds
Fordhook giant
Chard seed scattered in spaces in NE, NW, SE beds.
Still going strong; sharing 2 plants with chooks and the other 4 with neighbours. Used soapy water to deter bugs.
Sprouted them in cups outside, then transferred them to the hill.
Fordhook Giant.
Had holdovers from last year. Finally pulled those out in late June after second bolt. New crop not as productive, one has already bolted.
Silverado Chard seedlings acquired from Sloat Garden Center at 3rd Ave & Clement.
Silverbeet - cut down and regrowth from base
6 other plants died. The remaining 6 have survived the 2014/2015 winter.
silverbeet
peppermint seeds from greenmylife
Planted 2012, successfully overwintered 2013
Replacing the peppermint that did not overwinter

Julep mint.  Planted 2012.  Purchased from Seattle Tilth Edible Plant Sale.  I doubled my plant last year by trimming a few stems and rooting them in water.  I bought this mint specifically for Andy to make mint juleps.  He cooks the mint into a simple syrup that he keeps on-hand in the fridge.

2014:  Moved to Cobweb Cottage.

Chocolate mint. Planted 2012.  Purchased from Seattle Tilth Edible Plant Sale.  I doubled my plant last year by trimming a few stems and rooting them in water.  We're still not entirely certain what we're going to do with this mint, but at least it's doing well and giving us a nice crop.

2014:  Moved to Cobweb Cottage.
Did splendidly in full sun in a container until the wind picked up when the outer leaves got wind burnt and many died. Centre is still fine.

owner.location: Norway until we move country in August 2013

plantings.description: Planted in hanging box off of back porch. Purchased from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com). Lush and gorgeous, love this mint!
Planted by Emily and inherited by me. Currently in a pot in the backyard where it gets partial sun.
I like to have mint, but I needed to put it somewhere where it wouldn't be a nuisance.  This shady area seems just right.  Even the ferns don't seem to like it there.

attributes.description: Capiscum is a genus of flowering plants in the nightshade family Solanaceae that produces peppers. The Capiscum genus contains 20-27 species of peppers which vary in color, shape, size, and heat. 5 species are domesticated. Most peppers are green when unripe and change color as the fruit matures. The fruit of most species contains capsaicin, which gives hot peppers their spiciness. Bell peppers (Capsicum annuum) are an exception: they do not contain capsaicin due to a recessive gene, and are therefore not spicy. The Scoville scale is used to measure the relative heat of peppers. Bell peppers have a rating of 0-25 Scoville Heat Units (SHU), jalapenos are between 2,500-10,000 SHU. All peppers, regardless of species, prefer a long, warm growing season and well-drained soil high in organic matter. Seeds can be started indoors 8-10 weeks before hardening off and transplanting. In cooler climates, it can be preferable to grow peppers in containers indoors to extend the growing season and prevent frost from killing plants. Peppers have an upright growing habit and can benefit from staking to help the plant support the fruits.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant seedlings outside after hardening off

attributes.name: Welsh Onion
attributes.description: The Welsh Onion, or Bunching Onion, is a perennial species of onion native to China that is now grown around the world. Welsh Onions are very similar in taste and appearance to the common onion, Allium cepa. Large Welsh Onions resemble leeks and small ones look like chives. The main difference is that the stems of the Welsh Onion are hollow and their bulbs are barely thicker than their stems, which is why they are sometimes described as being "bulb-less." Plants form perennial clumps, which can be divided to propagate more onions. Welsh Onions can be grown as an annual in cooler regions where the plants cannot overwinter.

attributes.name: Artichoke
attributes.description: The globe artichoke is a variety of a species of thistle cultivated as a food. The budding artichoke flower-head is the edible part of the plant. It is a cluster of many budding small flowers (known as an "inflorescence") and bracts on an edible base. Once the buds bloom the head becomes coarse and barely edible. Artichokes are perennials in Zone 7 and warmer. They normally produce edible flower-heads during their second year, but recent cultivars such as 'Imperial Star' have been bred to produce in the first year. Other cultivars, such as 'Northern Star', have been bred to overwinter in more northern climates. There are green and purple varieties of artichoke. They are often steamed, sauted or braised, but can also be eaten raw.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors. In warmer zones, propagate "pups."

attributes.description: Squash is a genus of herbaceous vines that have large edible orange flowers that mature into gourds or cucurbits. Squash are commonly divided into two main groups: summer and winter. Summer squash have shorter growing times, a bushy growth habit, tender skin, and are quite prolific. Common types include cucumbers, zucchini, and pattypan squash. Winter squash take longer to mature, have a more sprawling growth habit, and produce gourds with thicker skins that can be stored for a few months. Common winter squash are pumpkins, butternut squash, acorn, and delicata. Most squash transplant poorly. If starting from seed indoors, use peat pots that can be directly transplanted into the soil to reduce root disturbance. More growing information is available in individual species entries.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors or outdoors

plantings.description:
45 day zucchini from seed

Planted 3. 1 sprouted but was eaten by earwigs. Planted a transplant yellow straightneck instead.
Jumbo pink banana squash

straightneck variety. I forgot to water the seedling the morning I ended up planting it, and then it hit 86F! It was wilting when it finally got planted a a deep watering.

The square foot gardening book says straightneck is a vining variety that I can grow vertically on a stake instead of having it spread out, so that's my plan.
Large spaghetti squash, planted just below the peppers and above the dead stump in the garden.
Surprise hardware store finding--99c acorn squash, looking quite robust. I've dropped it in at the end of the cucumbers.
Straightneck yellow squash. Only 1 this year. I can learn!

Trombetta di Albenga climbing summer squash. I planted this thinking it was a cucumber, since the seed was extremely slow to germinate. It twined around my sunflower all summer, flowered wildly, and produced two enormous squashes.
Used organic seeds

2 mounds of "Pumpkin: Kuri Red" aka Potimarron. The mounds are by the back fence. Each mound is a load of lawn clippings, with a pit dug in the middle and a couple of bucketloads of compost (from Clarissa, one of our compost bins) put in the centre.

Planted 3 seeds per mound.  This is what everyone says to do.  What they're less clear on is whether you thin them to the one strongest, or let all of them live?  

Because we have mynah birds who like to dig up our garden, I've tented over each mound with a recycled translucent plastic shopping bag: 3 bamboo skewers, point down, surround the seeds as a frame, then I put the plastic bag over them.  Then I use three more skewers to pin the bag in place, offset in the gaps between the first skewers.  I'm hoping this will protect the seeds/seedlings until they're established.

It's early to be planting these but I'm impatient, and it looks like we're well past the risk of frost.  This means we'll probably have squash in high summer.  Might plant some more in ~2 months time for an autumn crop.
Potimarron/kuri squash, planted at foot of a frame for them to grow up. Actually planted a handful of seeds in each of 2 locations, but will thin when they come up.
loofah gourds, specifically Not available on database.

Yates squash mix [courgette,scallopini][green,yellow] planted seeds in pots.

20191201 - planted out into Garden, and neighbour's plot,

attributes.description: Watercress is a semi-aquatic to aquatic perennial plant in the Brassica family whose leaves and stems have a clean, slightly peppery taste. In the wild, Watercress favors moderately cool climates and grows partially submerged in running water and flooded areas. It is one of the oldest known leaf vegetables eaten by humans. Watercress can be cultivated hydroponically, in containers, or in soil that is kept constantly wet. It can be harvested as sprouts or leaves.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed, transplants, or cuttings

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: eaten by catepillars

attributes.name: Bok Choy

attributes.description: A type of Chinese cabbage that does not form a head. It has smooth, dark or light green leaf blades and crisp white stalks that form a cluster similar to mustard greens or celery. It is often harvested while still small and tender, when it is around 10cm high. Winter hardy. Row spacing depends on desired harvest size.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors, or sow indoors and harden off before transplanting

plantings.description: In container garden
I seeded bok choy on 1 March (last frost date: 26 Feb) from a year 2013 package of seed. Seeds germinated in 9 days, and were quite robust; I had to thin around 26 April.

Another family favorite . We had slightly better success in 2013--a couple of the dozens we direct-sowed actually got to a size we could harvest off of.

2014: Like the spinach, I'm trying the triple threat--Grow Lights, wintersowing, and direct-sowing in different areas of the yard. :)
Set out a jug of baby bok choy out to see how it compares to my attempts to start it indoors under the Grow Light. And also for deliciousness.
Some test subjects for the system to help get it all going.
Will start planting this at the weekend, succession of crops to keep a good supply.
For the 2nd consecutive year, bok choy not productive. Bolted very fast. Very pest prone as well.
baby bok choy
Pak Choy seedlings that Dad grew.
Pak Choy. Free seed packet from the city council
purple pak choy

attributes.name: New Zealand yam
attributes.description: Yams grown in New Zealand originate from the South American Andes where they are known as oca. The sweet tubers are small, often about the size of a thumb, are pink-orange in colour and have a slightly shiny and ribbed surface.

plantings.description: self sown

#ocabreedersuk
self sown wild yams
These are self seeding EVERYWHERE. Covered a large area with more dirt, to encourage tubers, instead of just pulling these out like weeds

attributes.name: Feijoa
attributes.description: Feijoa, Pineapple Guava, or Guavasteen, is a perennial, evergreen shrub in the Myrtle (Myrtaceae) family. It is native to the temperate highlands and mountains of Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Feijoa is grown for it's fruits, which resemble small guavas, and as an ornamental. Feijoas are best planted from grafted saplings (as opposed to starting from seed) and will mature into a sprawling shrub if not pruned. They can also be grown in containers. They will produce fruit within 3-4 years of being transplanted. Most Feijoas are not self-fertile. The bright red flowers require pollination by 2-3 Feijoa trees of another variety nearby. The small fruit are green, ellipsoid, and the size of an egg. They taste like a cross between pineapple, apple, and mint, and have a clear, gelatinous seed pulp at the center surrounded by a firmer, slightly gritty opaque flesh. The fruit is eaten raw or added to smoothies. The edible flower petals can be added to salads. Fruit is best when allowed to ripen on the tree. A tarp or large cloth can be hung around the tree to catch fruit when it falls and prevent bruising. Feijoa requires between 100-200 hours of chilling during the winter and produces tastier fruit at moderate summer temperatures between 25-32C. Summer temperatures above 32C can negatively affect fruit set. Feijoa is somewhat drought tolerant.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant grafted sapling

attributes.name: Habanero Pepper
attributes.description: Habaneros are a very hot chili pepper variety that have a rating of 100,000-350,000 Scoville units and a floral aroma. The fruit is green when unripe. Various cultivars turn orange, red, white, brown, yellow, or purple as they ripen. Ripe fruit are typically 2-6 cm long.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant seedlings outside after hardening off

attributes.name: Fava Bean
attributes.description: The fava, or broad bean, is a species of flowering plant in the vetch and pea family Fabaceae. Unlike most beans, fava beans thrive in cooler weather and do not require trellising. They should be planted in early spring as soon as the soil can be worked. The broad, leathery pods contain 3-8 beans and grow on stiff stems that can reach heights of 1.8m.  Fava are planted for their edible beans, or as a cover crop to reduce winter erosion and increase nitrogen in the soil. Inoculants can increase yield and nitrogen production. The pods are commonly harvested while young, when they are about 15cm long. Fava beans are eaten in a myriad of ways: raw in salads, grilled, roasted, fried, pureed, and more.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors

attributes.description: Cayenne peppers are a cultivar of Capsicum annuum. They are members of the nightshade family, Solanaceae, and related to tomatoes and eggplant. The upright plants produce long, thin, red fruit that can be up to 25cm long. Cayenne peppers have a Scoville rating of 30,000 to 50,000 units and are slightly hotter than jalapenos. They are generally dried and ground to make cayenne spice, but they can also be used whole or in a thin, vinegar-based sauce.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant seedlings outside after hardening off

plantings.description: unidentified variety, probably serrano pepper
Hatch Green chile. Seed from Sandia Seed Company. For chile verde.
NuMex Joe Parker chile -- medium hot. From Sandia Seed Company
Actually a thai chilli pepper.  Hoping this will overwinter.
NuMex Heritage Big Jim chile. From Sandia seed company. For chile verde and chile rellenos. 23 June 2013 -- Planted in left flowerbed, forward along wall.
Fish pepper from Thorne Farm, bought at Maryland Sheep and Wool
Poblano pepper
Mixture of jalapeno & cayenne, + 1 of "Jannie Oliver's Hot Carrot" which we picked up off the dead & dying!
On bed room windowsills, 2 of Chilli 'Black Pearl', 1 of Chilli 'Peach Habanero', 1 of Chilli 'Rokita'. Remaining productive for over 3 years now.

Fish pepper (from D. Landreth Seed Co., 2011).  No, not hoping for any peppers from this planting this summer -- just want to successfully get a plant going to over-winter for next year.  I had a successfully spouted seed earlier this year, but it didn't quite make it all the way to the growing season.

6 each of Friar's Hat and Hungarian Black - seeds from W Robinson & Son, bought at the Harrogate Autumn Flower Show. Despite always keeping them as houseplants, I've previously stuck to spring sowings only - keen to see if we get as good germination from autumn sowing :-)
jalapeno

attributes.name: Chayote
attributes.description: Chayote is a tender perennial in the Cucurbitaceae family grown for its edible gourds, roots, stems, and leaves. Unlike other cucurbits like squash, cucumbers, and melons, Chayote's small gourds have a single, large, flattened seed or pit. Some varieties have spiny fruits. Chayote is native to Mesoamerica and thrives in a subtropical to tropical climate, although it can be grown in other regions in containers. It needs 120-150 frost-free days to reach harvest. Like cucumbers, it has a sprawling growth pattern and benefits from trellising - fruit will rot if it sits on the soil. It's pale green fruit can be 10-20cm long and resembles a flattened, wrinkled pear. It's green to white flesh has a mild taste like a cross between a potato and a cucumber. It is usually lightly cooked like summer squash. The tubers are starchy and eaten like potatoes. The shoots and heart-shaped leaves can be added to salads and stir-fries.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed whole fruit outdoors

plantings.description: It's not quite mature enough for planting, but it was already perforated by bugs, so let's see if it survives.

Chayotes, if left to lie about, will start to germinate.  I planted two such babies and waited.  They grow quickly, and this spring they just exploded with fruit.  They've kept me busy directing the climbing stems and tying wires for them.
grew directly from fruit.
It was giving to me by my boyfriend.

attributes.name: New Zealand Spinach
attributes.description: New Zealand Spinach is a warm-weather spinach alternative that is not directly related to spinach, but has a similar flavor and texture. The plant has a bushy, spreading habit and pointed, succulent, bright green leaves. Leaves can be eaten fresh in salads or cooked like spinach. Unlike spinach, New Zealand Spinach thrives in warm temperatures and will not survive the first hard frost. Seeds germinate slowly and benefit from being soaked before planting.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors after last frost, thin seedlings to 30cm

plantings.description: Near the gate, in the shade under the tree.

Got some seedlings started under glass.  People tell me I should plant direct in the ground, but the weather's been so hot I didn't like to try.  My last couple of warrigal greens came from seedlings and worked out fine, so I'm going for another batch now.
Near the shed. It's starting to spread out, which is ace.
Near the gate, in the shade under the tree.  It doesn't seem to be doing all that well :(
Bloomsdale spinach, between garlic

Old seed, not sure if still viable. Sprouting on paper towel in hot water cupboard.

5 November: Forgot to water and they got dried out too much and started going mildewy. Composted them.
Wild volunteer behind the trampoline

attributes.description: Perennial spring vegetable often sown from crowns. The vegetable has a mild flavor with earthy undertones. When mature and reproducing, the plant creates tall, stout stems with feathery foliage and small red berries.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant crowns outside, or start seeds indoors

plantings.description: From Fruit Trees And More in Sydney. Section of plot closest to house.
asparagus bed. planted crowns in 2010. This year should be the year they are large enough for eating but I am skeptical.
It's doing well.
Got some spears this year.
3 green, 2 purple

owner.location: North of the River Perth, Western Australia

plantings.description: I planted five plants in each bag, in 2011.  These were cut hugely for the first time, yummy!  I need to re-pot this year, when planting time comes round, as the bags I planted them in decayed hugely in our awful 2012 here in the UK

New asparagus bed put in in a "special" bed - full sun at noon in midsummer, full shade at noon in winter, and in fact shaded almost completely for most of winter. Soil was the partly-improved stuff I made for the main bed last year that's been sitting for six months. Root clumps are from my mum's garden, long-established plants with good tuber stock. Will see how they transplant.

owner.location: Thornlie, Perth, Western Australia (southern suburbs, Bassendean sands)

plantings.description:
Again, the chooks are an issue. This is my first time with asparagus - fingers crossed!

Update 2013-09-21: Now growing happily inside temp fence; 5 spears seen today! 1 on each of 2 corms, 3 on the third.

One seedling asparagus from those "herb pots", planted in a random spot to see what happened. It's in a zone that receives some water for the grape vine. Survived first summer (surprising), has browned for winter as of June 2013, not planning to cut for shoots until spring 2014.

owner.location: Thornlie, Perth, Western Australia (southern suburbs, Bassendean sands)

plantings.description: Between Bath 1 and Lemon Tree
Jersey Supreme crowns
I dug out a 20 foot row, 9 inches deep.  I put in some phos fertilizer.  I set the tubers on mounds then covered each one up 2 inches.  Leaves on top.
Bought at Fleet Farm.  9 of the 10 came up.  Slow growing.  Appear as wispy tiny things.  Hard to see at first as weeds come with them.
4 very large, deep wooden containers with 5 one year old crowns in each one, two more years until a harvest
One row

attributes.name: Shallot

attributes.description: Shallots are a type of small onion with a subtle, distinguished flavor. The bulb is covered in papery red skin tinted rust, gold, or purple and has a tapered oblong shape with multiple cloves. They can be used fresh or dried in a variety of dishes.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed, thin to 5cm when seedlings are 3cm tall

plantings.description: in third section
Planted red Dutch shallots in the community garden, covered mostly in leaf-gro compost. Kind of an experiment.
Planted between the pepper plants, forward along the wall. 23 June 2013 -- at least one is sprouting.
Picked these up at Plants Plus on Leith St.  You plant them from bulbs and they form clusters, a bit like garlic but bigger.  Excited to grow them since they are so expensive to buy.
Actually these are eshallots planted from bulb
Spring Onions. Awesome to cut and regrow. Perfectly fine through summer and winter and still producing.
Second section.
Gray shallot
"Green onion" (not in crop database)

One package, planted on the left side of the garden, accross and above garlic. 
Planted mixed with red onions.

attributes.name: Endive
attributes.description: Curly Endive is a narrow-leaved member of the Chicory family (versus Escarole, which is broad-leaved). It grows in loose heads of narrow, green, lacey leaves with curled tips. The head is often tied together when it is 25cm tall to blanch the inner leaves. The outer leaves have a slightly bitter flavor, and the inner leaves have a subtle sweetness and more delicate texture. All of the leaves sweeten slightly with frost or cooking. Curly Endive can be eaten raw in salads or cooked in soups, stews, and other dishes.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant outside after hardening off seedlings

plantings.description: Belgian endive (Cicoria Witloof di Bruxelles) from Pagano seed company. Transplanted on 02 June 2013

attributes.name: Tomatillo
attributes.description: The tomatillo is a member of the Nightshade family. The plant bears a resemblance to tomato plants and benefits from pruning and trellising. The fruit of the tomatillo plant is small, round, and green or purple. It is covered in a paper husk that splits open when the fruit is ready for harvest. Tomatillos are native to Mexico and can be eaten raw or cooked. They have a citrusy, tart, and tangy lemon flavor.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant seedlings outside after hardening off

plantings.description: Tomatillo seeds from Lake Valley seed company. I've never had much luck with tomatillos, since they're very vulnerable to wind damage, but we'll see how they do in the ground this year. 23 June 2013 -- all outside in pots now. 2 growing well, 2 stunted. 27 July 2013 -- transplanted to larger pots.
planted 3 seeds each in 2 pots

Got totally snailified within weeks. Boo.

attributes.name: Sorrel
attributes.description: Sorrel is a hardy perennial herb that produces some of the earliest spring and latest fall greens. The plant has deep roots and long, wide, tapering leaves with juicy stems. Leaves have a sour, tangy, lemony taste and are delicious in salads, soups, and sandwiches. In the summer, Sorrel will bolt, producing reddish-green flowers and setting seed. This bolting can be reduced by harvesting consistently. Even if Sorrel sets seed in the summer, it will produce another set of edible leaves in the fall.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors or root division

plantings.description: Did curiously well. Survived winter all on its own too.
Scattering of seeds next to rosemary and in front of rasps, both in West bed.
french variant, under the laundry umbrella (needs to be moved because it is too large now).

These are in a spot that gets afternoon sun but is shaded in the morning.  They seem to be doing well!

attributes.name: brandywine tomato
attributes.description: The Brandywine tomato plant is an heirloom cultivar of the species, with large potato-leaved foliage and which bears large pink beefsteak-shaped fruit, popularly considered among the best tasting available.  Brandywine tomatoes can bear fruit up to 1.5 lbs (0.7 kg), requiring 80 to 100 days to reach maturity, making it among the slowest maturing varieties of common tomato cultivars. Brandywine has been described as having a "great tomatoey flavor"

plantings.description: variety: yellow brandywine

Should take 90 to 100 days to mature.

2019-11-23 planted out into bed near garage, and bigger vege bed
Solanu strain, in the center. This is under a greenhouse cover for the early part of the season to keep warm.

attributes.name: Runner Bean
attributes.description: The Runner, or Multiflora, Bean is a vining plant in the Fabaceae (legume) family that is native to Central America. It is sometimes called the Butter Bean, which can also refer to the Lima Bean, a separate species. The Runner Bean differs from other beans in that it can be grown as a perennial where the ground does not freeze. Runner Beans are grown for their edible beans and as an ornamental: plants produce brilliant red flowers that attract hummingbirds and multicolored seeds. Some varieties have white flowers. The seed pods have a knife-like shape and are usually green, but some purple cultivars exist. Pods are 15-30cm long and contain 6-10 2.5cm seeds. Different varieties have different colored seeds. Seeds can eaten fresh or as dried beans, but must be cooked to remove toxins. Blooms can be added to salads. Young pods can be cooked like green beans. Roots are eaten by indigenous peoples in Central America. Runner Beans benefit from trellising.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors once soil temperatures are above 10C

plantings.description:
Seeds may be a little elderly, and the last lot I planted (from another packet) didn't come up at all. Well, if they don't, they don't.

attributes.name: Common Fig
attributes.description: The fig is a perennial, flowering, deciduous shrub or small tree in the Mulberry (Moraceae) family. Figs are native to the Middle East and western Asia and are grown for their fruit, which are also known as figs, and as an ornamental plant. In the right climate, they can grow as tall as 10 meters, but they can also be grown in containers and brought indoors in the winter in cooler regions. The plant has smooth white bark, deeply lobed fragrant leaves, and multiple, spreading trunks. Flowers are often pollinated by fig wasps, and develop into 3-5cm long fruit with green skin that, depending on the variety, can ripen to a deep purple. Figs need to ripen fully on the tree before harvest. They are ripe when they droop and are soft to the touch. If they ooze a white sap when they are pulled from the tree, they are not ripe. Fig trees have an aggressive root system that searches for groundwater in aquifers, ravines, and cracks in rocks. Once established, they can tolerate seasonal drought and are affected by few pests. Figs are propagated through cuttings or division, and generally produce fruit the year after planting. In warmer climates, they can produce two crops, one in early summer, and the other in fall.
attributes.sowing_method: Cuttings, young tree, or seeds

plantings.description: Two figs, of questionable health.

planted two figs called BROWN TURKEY FIG
ABOUT 18 INCHES SEEDLINGS bought from Virginia nursery

Kadota. Planted in the spring from Green Thumb Nursery. Has FMV. Fruiting as of August 2015, same year it was planted. 13 figs this year!

UPDATE 3/21/2016: 4 figs reached maturity and were eaten, and another 3 reached maturity during a cold spell and dropped before I discovered they were ripe. One fig did not drop at all, and is still on the tree, possibly to ripen at some unexpected moment this spring. The fig is setting a significant breba crop this year, at least as big as last year's fall crop. This is a wonderful and productive tree.
6 feet tall after 2 years and bearing a lot of fruit!   Just have to get to it before the birds do.
Sapling from the plant at my parents

attributes.name: Cape Gooseberry
attributes.description: Cape Gooseberries, or Physalis, are a plant species in the genus Physalis and family Solanaceae. They have slightly velvety heart-shaped leaves and produce smooth bright yellow or orange berries wrapped in a papery husk or calyx. They are originally from Peru and are related to tomatillos and husk/ground cherries. Cape Gooseberries grow well without fertilizer and in sandy to poor soils, but they need to be protected from wind. The fruit is sweet with a mildly tart flavor, tastes a bit like pineapple, and can be eaten raw, made into jams, or baked into pies. Unripe fruits are poisonous, harvest when the husk has lost color and dried out.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant seedlings outside after hardening off.

plantings.description: I let these grow like weeds in my garden (the planting date is fake).  They self seed everywhere.
They don't like the frost so the plant is stunted. Will need to transplant to a bigger pot and put frost sock on it to get a better crop next year.
Little lanterns, and also Inca berries.  The Inca berries being a James Wong variety.

attributes.description: Butternut squash is a winter squash cultivar that produces long squash with smooth, tan-yellow skin and a rounded compartment of seeds at the bottom. Flesh is deep orange and firm with a sweet, nutty taste. Butternut squash becomes deeper orange and sweeter and richer as it ripens. Like other squash, it grows on sprawling vines. If starting seeds indoors, use peat pots and directly transplant them into the soil to reduce root disturbance. Harvest squash before any hard frosts and cure. Winter squash can be stored for up to 3 months in a cool, dry, well-ventilated place.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed. If planting indoors, harden off before transplanting seedlings outside.

plantings.description: Old seed experiment -- planted about 20 in one hill in hope that one will germinate.
Never had much success with these, we shall see.
Actually planted a handful of seeds in each of 3 locations, but will thin to three when they come up.

Transplanted from old QAPP plot after a couple months in the ground. Went through a shock period & then started to grow. I'm amazed that it's survived! Surely would've been bigger if not uprooted at this stage, but it's flourishing now.

attributes.name: Catnip
attributes.description: Catnip is a herbaceous perennial in the mint family, Lamiaceae. It resembles mint, with triangular, coarse-toothed leaves, square stems, and small, pink, white, purple, or blue flowers. Like mint, it can become invasive, so it is best planted in containers. Catnip is used an ornamental, to make herbal tea, and as a companion plant. It is deer-resistant and attracts beneficial insects like bees and butterflies and deters pests like flea beetles, Japanese beetles, aphids, weevils, ants, squash bugs and mice. It also attracts cats because it contains the chemical nepetalactone, which can cause cats to enter a brief state of euphoria.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors before frost, or outdoors after last frost

plantings.description: Thriving and taking over.
Near the carport. Bought this for E's cat who didn't like it. Now kind of annoyed that it's taking up space.
Something simple to have has a test subjects for my automated hydroponics system.
2016:  Sprinkled a bunch of seeds on dirt, then watered.

attributes.name: Mizuna
attributes.description: Mizuna is a cool weather salad green in the Brassica family. It has a mild, slightly peppery taste and heavily serrated, feathery leaves. Leaves can be harvested at their baby or adult sizes, between 7 and 15cm. Be sure to harvest before the plant flowers. Leaves can be eaten raw in salads and on sandwiches, sauted, or stir-fried.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed outdoors

attributes.name: Spearmint
attributes.description: Spearmint is a variety of mint that has a more delicate, sweet flavor than Peppermint. Like Peppermint, Spearmint is a perennial herb with square-shaped stems and pink, purple, or white flowers. Mint is often grown in pots to prevent it from overtaking the garden with its invasive, spreading rhizome root structure. The leaves are most aromatic before the plant flowers and can be used fresh, dried, or frozen. Mint's strongly scented leaves confuse the pests of carrots, tomatoes, alliums, and brassicas, and deter flea beetles.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed. If planting indoors, harden off before transplanting seedlings outside.

plantings.description: this has had a bit of a hard time, but is peeking out from under a pile of hay at the moment

This species, also know as Hortel here in Brazil, grows really fast and is very nice to make iced-teas.
rooting in water

attributes.name: Bay Laurel
attributes.description:
Bay Laurel is an aromatic evergreen tree or large shrub native to the Mediterranean. It can be grown in soil or in containers. It has glossy dark green leaves, 
yellow flowers, and dark purplish-black fruits. The plant's leaves are used as seasoning in cooking and are best harvested in the morning when the fragrance oils are strongest. Bay Laurel can also be grown as an ornamental or topiary. Plant trees in an area where they are protected from wind to prevent cold winter winds from damaging foliage.
attributes.sowing_method: Young tree or cutting

plantings.description: Probably a little stunted, could be because it's in a pot, but it provides me with what I need.

attributes.description: The peach tree is a deciduous tree native to Northwest China that produces stone, or drupe, fruits. It belongs to the genus Prunus which includes the cherry, apricot, almond, and plum. The peach is classified with the almond in the subgenus Amygdalus because their stones are corrugated rather than smooth. Peaches and nectarines are the same species - nectarines have a recessive gene that makes their skin smooth rather than fuzzy. Cultivated peaches are divided into two groups: clingstones and freestones, depending on whether the flesh sticks to the stone or not. Peaches can have white or yellow fuzzy skin. Yellow peaches usually have an acidic tang coupled with sweetness. White peaches are very sweet with little acidity. Most cultivars require 500 hours of chilling around 0 to 10 C during the winter, and hot temperatures in the summer to ripen fruit. Some varieties are self-pollinating, while others require pollination by a peach tree of another variety with the same bloom period within 50 feet. Peaches should be thinned to 7-12cm apart when fruit are 2-3cm in diameter to increase mature fruit size. Standard and dwarf rootstocks are available. Dwarf trees can grow to 3 meters, standard to 4.5 meters. Depending on the size chosen, the tree will bear fruit within 2-4 years of planting.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant bare-root plant

plantings.description: We've been fighting disease on this one, so who knows how long it'll be around....
both are products of random seed throwing.

We have had a bout 16 golden queen peaches pop up from seed over the last year, I've had them in pots until we finished expanding the chicken run (and they were big enough to handle the chooks).  Stone mulching around the roots is a definate requirement.  Once they are a bit bigger, I'll be grafting on some more peach varieties to them.

Nectarine, just coming in to bud.

Update 2013-09-21: blossom all gone, leaf buds appearing. This is the smallest tree and furthest from the water source, so the one I'm watching most closely.
Update 2014-11-06: Had severe case of leaf-curl by the end of last summer. Treated with seaweed extract while leaves were off, seems to be gone but tree still growing very slowly. Neighbour trees are flourishing.
Redhaven peach from Stark Brothers. Planted as "dwarf supreme"

attributes.name: Aloe Vera
attributes.description: Aloe Vera is an evergreen succulent with thick, fleshy leaves with serrated edges. It can be grown outdoors in USDA Plant Hardiness Zones 9-11 or indoors anywhere. Like all succulents, Aloe Vera does best with bright light and in arid conditions. Aloe is often grown for ornamental and medicinal uses: the juice from it's leaves is frequently applied to sunburns and other wounds.
attributes.sowing_method: Cuttings or "pups"

plantings.description: gifted by sister's mother in law from sheohar, bihar
Been growing for two years. Originally a clipping from a bigger plant in NSW.
Thriving even though it's being smothered by other plants.
Repotted an aloe vera belonging to attlebish.  I separated 4 small shoots and put them in tiny containers, to give back to her or keep or trade, not sure yet.

On the windowsill. Planted about a year ago, now has 2 extra seedlings and is going strong.

Still growing well in Feb 2015, and has been used for burns.

Removed the extra seedlings in June 2015 as it was overflowing.

Opened up the old one to repot and split out the seedlings, and found there were actually 11 small plants. Let's see how many survive now I've broken half the roots in separating them.

Update: They all survived. I gave 4 away to Mum, as hers had died.
Actually 'San Francisco Fog' tomatoes. Planted in a barrel.

Tomato, Hybrid Big Beef VFFNT.  Produces big, beefy 10-12 ounce tomatoes.  Maturity: 73 days.  These grew huge (1-2 ft) before I could get them in the garden.  Planted 3-25-15.  Could start later. I gave Ma a bunch.
Bonny Best tomatoes
unknown variety
Tomato my mum gave me, in a pot. already has tomatoes on it.
Pruden's Purple Tomato from Ferry-Morse. Seeds bought in 2017.

Beefsteak Select. Kings#3645, by 2022

Planted out in main garden next to fence.  Did not do well.

attributes.description: The plum is a fruit of the subgenus Prunus of the genus Prunus. The Prunus genus also includes the cherry, apricot, almond, and peach. Within the subgenus Prunus, there are many species. The two largest species groups are European Plums (Prunus domestica) and Japanese Plums (Prunus salicina). Apricots are also classified as a section of the Prunus subgenus. The skin of plums can be coated with a waxy bloom or it can be shiny. Plums can be purple, green, yellow, or red. Shape varies from oval to globular. Plums can be dried to make prunes. European Plums require 800-900 hours of chilling during the winter, Japanese Plums require 300-500. Some varieties are self-pollinating, but all plum trees benefit from a pollination partner with the same bloom time within 15 meters. Standard and dwarf rootstocks are available. Dwarf trees can grow to 3 meters, standard to 4.5 meters. Depending on the size chosen, the tree will bear fruit within 3-6 years of planting.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant bare-root plant

plantings.description: Yellow flesh, red skin plum
Victoria Plum, planted on the lawn.

Plum - Mariposa
Plum - Narabeen

Planted very close, intention being to keep them small.
A duo plum - greengage and Victoria, I think. Unlikely to give us fruit this year. Doing well, starting to grow nicely!
variety czar, espallied in front of the north-west facing wall of the house. Lots of growth, but no fruit yet
Bought a Santa Rosa and a Mariposa Plum, both on dwarf stock from one of the big online providers. I planted them on top of a hugulculture and filled in the hole with soaked, processed cow manure.
in large hexagon raised bed. it's a burgundy-leafed ornamental variety, but the plums are edible, if small.

owner.location: East Coast, Central Vancouver Island, BC, Canada

plantings.description: The first was a seedling from a yellow skinned dwarf plum, the second is an unknown varient that sprang up from seed about two years back.  I've had the kids throwing seed down there for the last couple of years so it could be from a wide variety of plum.

Santa Rosa plum, beginning to bud.
Update 2013-09-21: In full leaf, healthy and strong.

I have done a trio planting of 3 trees with slightly different fruiting times. 2 Japanese plums will pollinate each other and the third is a golden gage that will be pollinated by a prune already growing nearby. The trees will be pruned to grown as one plant. A great way to have variety in a small space.
This damson plum was here when I moved in.
Stanley plum from Stark Brothers. Planted as "dwarf supreme"

a "fruit salad" tree where all the grafts except plum are dead. 

Tried grafting additional peach scions on this spring. I think they died.

attributes.name: Raspberry
attributes.description: Raspberries are a perennial plant with erect to trailing canes that often have spines or thorns. The plants produce fruit in their second year of growth, but some "primocane" varieties exist that flower and fruit their first year. Canes are light green to blue in hue with alternate, compound leaves. Fruits are sweet, many-seeded, and hollow.
attributes.sowing_method: Transplant from roots or juvenile plants.

plantings.description: Bought from Stark Bros. Latham red raspberry.

1 Unknown variety from Lara's Mum's garden, 1 Willamette, 1 Diggers Gold and one Autumn Bliss. The first three produced no fruit their first summer, have left them alone. The Autumn Bliss has produced 1 fruit, maybe a punnet more's worth on the way. Autumn Bliss has a resident mantid.
We have a variety of different raspberry plants scattered around the yard.
these are a heirloom variety called "Everlasting".  They generally give two or three crops a season.
3 new raspberries join along the back fence.
Need to check, but a mix of yellow and black raspberries.

Original got swamped by the blackberries; new plant bought from Poundworld.

Plant acquired when my neighbours changed the boundary fences slightly! Now self-seeds well enough that I keep getting more...

These were on the property when we moved in. We transplanted and they eventually took after a long time.  They are now very productive and come up every where. Planted just outside the garden along an old fence line.
yellow and 'heritage' varieties. Yellow raspberries are quite sweet, and the birds don't notice them so much.
bought canby raspberry canes (thornless) to plant in the patch
Four everbearing and two golden raspberries

4 different varieties. 2 golden (1 everbearing, 1 junebearing); 1 red everbearing; 1 black (planted well away from the others in a different part of the orchard).

I didn't really mark them well to tell which is which (except the black one of course). Shortly after planting them there was an unexpected hot spell and they got really stressed and one I think is dead and another is not doing too well but is hanging on; the other 2 are looking really happy though. I hope they do well... I love raspberries!

UPDATE: As of 3/21/2016 the surviving raspberries have leafed out after the winter!
Keeping in a 'pot' to avoid it taking over the garden and keeping it mobile so I can control how much sun it gets in high summer.

Bought one plant, and got a half-dozen starts from my folks' house, where they have a big, old patch of raspberries.  I think they are fine-tasting.  I don't know what variety they are.  I expect the kids will eat them all.  The are spreading all over the patch this year.  
6/10/15: The berries are buried under a ton of new foliage.  They are just starting to ripen.  
7/8/15:  I cut the foliage back last month. These have been ripening over the last few weeks and are almost done now.  Purchased plant has elongated berries, and are very sweet.  Plants from folks' have round berries and are not as sweet, although there is some variation.  Some have more flavor than others.
One summer-bearing red fruit, one fall-bearing gold fruit
No idea what variety it is other than being red.
Bought from Stark Bros. Fall red everbearing raspberry.
Called "Broccoletti" on the label.

Seeds purchased in 2009, not sure if any will germinate

Update: lots of germination, bolted fast and little harvest. Collected seeds for next year, and seeing some self-seeding in August.
inn poly tunnel
Side sprouting brocoli
